Boeing\u2019s quarterly plane deliveries.title: Boeing’s quarterly plane deliveries fall to lowest levels in nearly three years
Boeing\u2019s quarterly plane deliveries.text:
Boeing Co. delivered 83 commercial airplanes in the first quarter, which was its lowest quarterly total in nearly three years.  The company’s delivery numbers marked a steep decline from the 157 units it delivered in the fourth quarter and the 130 units it delivered in the first quarter of 2023. Boeing’s latest quarterly total, disclosed on Tuesday, was its worst since the second quarter of 2021, when it delivered 79 airplanes, according to FactSet data. Analysts tracked by FactSet were expecting 105 deliveries for the latest quarter, based on five estimates.  Read: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun’s pay climbed 45% last year Shares of Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.26%
       are falling 1.5% in midday action Tuesday. The stock is on track to log its seventh session in a row of declines, which would make for its longest losing streak since Sept. 13, 2023, when it declined for nine sessions consecutively, accordingly to Dow Jones Market Data. The stock is down 31% so far this year. Boeing’s delivery performance for the first quarter comes as the aerospace company has been lowering its production rate in response to recent safety incidents. Chief Executive David Calhoun recently said he intends to step down from his role at the end of the year. See also: Boeing CFO says cash flow to be hit by production delays Rival Airbus SE 
        AIR,
        -0.92%
       also put out new figures, showing that it has delivered 142 units to 45 customers over the course of 2024 to date. That number was 127 for the same period in 2023. FactSet doesn’t list a consensus expectation for Airbus deliveries.  Shares of the French aircraft manufacturer are down 3.4% in midday action. Opinion: Boeing’s CEO is departing, but the company’s problems run far deeper Alphabet shares surge after Google’s parent posts better-than-expected earnings and announces its first cash dividend, Microsoft posts 31% quarterly growth in Azure cloud-computing revenue, and Exxon Mobil’s earnings miss estimates. Inflation and Rates Are a Problem, Why J.title: Inflation and Rates Are a Problem, Why Jamie Dimon May Be Right This Time. And 5 Other Things to Know Before the Market Opens.
Inflation and Rates Are a Problem, Why J.text:
Jamie Dimon probably bought his crystal ball from a thrift shop—remember his “economic hurricane” prediction in 2022? But the 
        JPMorgan
       CEO may be on to something in his latest annual letter to shareholders. His forecast that interest rates could reach 8% might seem outlandish but Dimon’s warning around inflation and rates staying higher than expected ought to be taken more seriously. Wednesday’s consumer price index is expected to show inflation ticking back up to 3.4% in March, from 3.2% in February. The Federal Reserve’s 2% target is proving elusive. Dimon has several longer-term inflationary concerns, including increased military spending as global conflicts intensify, the fiscal spending needed to transition to a green economy, and rising healthcare costs. When, or if, the Fed reaches its target the battle won’t be over. For example, Spain’s inflation rate fell below 2% in June last year but it has proved to be a one-off and now sits at 3.2%. The prospect of interest rates staying higher for longer has been in and out of fashion over the past year, but it’s back in vogue. The market’s confidence that March would bring about the start of lower borrowing costs has been replaced with uncertainty about whether June will be the date for the first cut. The market is pricing in a 51% chance of that, according to CME’s FedWatch tool. Even the probability of a cut by July is slipping—currently at 70%, down from 92% a month ago. But, crucially, investors don’t share Dimon’s economic pessimism. Stocks have reached record levels this year. The market sees resilient economic data pointing to robust corporate earnings and will remain happy as long as inflation is trending lower and rate cuts are in the cards at some point this year. Earnings season, starting in earnest Friday, and Wednesday’s inflation data will test those two conditions. —Callum Keown Inflation and interest rates may remain higher than investors expect thanks to costs tied to increased military investments, climate change mitigation efforts, global supply-chain reconfigurations, and rising healthcare costs, JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said in his annual letter to shareholders. What’s Next: The bank boss said that small changes in interest rates today may have less impact on inflation in the future than many people believe. He warned to be prepared for a very broad range of interest rates from 2% to 8% or even more. However his prediction contrasts with that of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, who signaled last week that interest-rate cuts this year are still on the table. —Rebecca Ungarino and Angela Palumbo Traders now see the possibility the Federal Reserve won’t cut interest rates as sharply this year, which is a view supported by the stronger-than-expected March jobs report. Rather than the six or seven cuts expected in January, some traders now see just a couple, and some see the possibility of no cuts. What’s Next: Some Fed officials have said in the past week they are concerned inflation declines could stall. Wednesday’s consumer price index for March, expected to rise 0.3% from the prior month, could help make the argument for the Fed waiting a while longer to cut rates. —Liz Moyer President Joe Biden is still trying to expand the number of people eligible for student debt forgiveness, announcing another plan to help nearly 30 million federal loan borrowers, including parents who took out loans to pay for their children’s education. It is still vulnerable to legal challenges. What’s Next: More than 40% of Generation Z swing-state voters surveyed by Bloomberg and Morning Consult late last year said Biden wasn’t doing enough about student debt. If this latest plan moves forward, some borrowers could have their debts canceled before the November election. —Elizabeth O’Brien and Janet H. Cho 
Blackstone’s
       planned $10 billion purchase of the upscale apartment buildings owner 
        Apartment Income REIT,
       or AIR Communities (AIRC), could be a sign that the asset manager sees an opportunity to snap up some real estate, especially in the rental properties market. What’s Next: The transaction was unanimously approved by AIR’s board of directors and is expected to close in the third quarter. As a condition of the transaction, AIR Communities suspended payment of its quarterly dividend.  —Janet H. Cho 
Spirit Airlines
       will delay some of its deliveries from European plane maker 
        Airbus,
       a decision that could make some aircraft available for use by rival carriers after capacity problems created by U.S. rival 
        Boeing’s
       regulatory, production, and safety issues. For Spirit, the move will boost liquidity by $340 million over the next two years. What’s Next: Spirit CEO Ted Christie said the change would help Spirit bolster profitability and strengthen its balance sheet. Spirit also expects to receive $150 million to $200 million as part of a compensation agreement with 
        RTXCorp.’s
       Pratt & Whitney because of issues with its GTF engines. —Callum Keown and Janet H. Cho Be sure to join this month’s Barron’s Daily virtual stock exchange challenge and show us your stuff. Each month, we’ll start a new challenge and invite newsletter readers—you!—to build a portfolio using virtual money and compete against the Barron’s and MarketWatch community. Everyone will start with the same amount and can trade as often or as little as they choose. We’ll track the leaders and at the end of the challenge the winner whose portfolio has the most value will be announced in The Barron’s Daily newsletter. Are you ready to compete? Join the challenge and pick your stocks here. —Newsletter edited by Liz Moyer, Patrick O’Donnell, Rupert Steiner Buying stocks after the “final rate hike” in a cycle demands perfect timing. BP Expects Higher Oil, Gas Production to.title: BP Expects Higher Oil, Gas Production to Boost Profit -- 2nd Update
BP Expects Higher Oil, Gas Production to.text:
By Christian Moess Laursen BP expects a boost to first-quarter profit from higher oil, gas and low-carbon energy production, while lower natural-gas prices will temper gains. The British energy major on Tuesday backed its guidance of higher upstream production--the extraction of raw crude oil and natural gas--in the first quarter, with higher output in oil production and operations and slightly higher production of gas and low-carbon energy compared with the previous quarter. In the fourth quarter, BP's oil production was 1.42 million of oil-equivalent barrels a day, while it produced 899,000 BOE a day of gas and low-carbon energy. Its shares were up 1.7% to 518.00 pence at 0743 GMT, having climbed 13% over the past three months. The update follows that of BP's closest rival Shell, which on Friday lifted its guidance for first-quarter production of integrated gas and liquefied natural gas. The London-based oil-and-gas companies are the first European majors to provide updates on first-quarter production and earnings amid concerns that natural-gas businesses could face pressure after prices dropped on year in 2023, following a spike in 2022 when Russia invaded Ukraine. BP said lower natural-gas prices will likely hit both its gas and low-carbon energy segment as well as its oil production and operations segment this quarter. It said Brent averaged $83.16 a barrel in the quarter compared to $84.34 in the preceding quarter, while gas prices averaged $2.25 per million British thermal units versus $2.88. Additionally, profit from its gas and low-carbon energy segment is expected to take a hit of $400 million to $600 million, mainly due to lower natural-gas prices and the devaluation of the Egyptian pound. Price lags on production in the Gulf of Mexico and the United Arab Emirates are expected to drive a $300 million-$600 million dent to profit from oil production and operations. However, its gas marketing and trading result is expected to be strong, the company added. In the first quarter of 2023, the FTSE 100-listed energy group reported gas and low-carbon energy production of 969,000 BOE a day and oil production of 1.36 million BOE a day. BP also said its net debt is expected to increase in the first quarter, mainly reflecting a working-capital build plus phasing of capital expenditure and divestment and other proceeds, as previously guided. For the full-year, BP still sees slightly higher upstream production than in 2023, with higher oil production and lower gas and low-carbon energy production. Write to Christian Moess Laursen at christian.moess@wsj.com Tech stocks launched a solid rebound early Friday as Alphabet and Microsoft earnings brought renewed optimism to the sector. Forget Rate Cuts. Here\u2019s What the S.title: Forget Rate Cuts. Here’s What the Stock Market Really Needs Now.
Forget Rate Cuts. Here\u2019s What the S.text:
Earnings season is coming—and it might just be what the stock market needs to drive the next leg higher.  First-quarter earnings kick off this coming week, with companies such as 
        Delta Air Lines,
Constellation Brands,
JPMorgan Chase,
       and 
        Fastenal
       set to report their profits. Results will probably come in higher than analysts’ current estimates. In the past four quarters, aggregate earnings per share for the 
        S&P 500
       have beaten expectations by 7.1% on average, according to Chris Senyek, chief investment strategist at Wolfe Research, so it would take quite a sea change for companies to suddenly miss.  Beats might not be quite as large as in recent quarters—a decelerating economy could lead to slower earnings growth—but they are still likely. Senyek estimates that companies in the S&P 500 should beat earnings by a “very healthy” 4% to 5%. That’s not only plausible, but highly achievable, given that analysts covering S&P 500 companies have reduced first-quarter earnings forecasts by 2.5% this year, making it easier for companies to turn in better-than-forecast results.  Beats alone won’t be enough, though. The market will also need to see encouraging forward-looking guidance from management teams to justify higher valuations. After gaining 25% since its October low, the S&P 500 trades at 20.1 times expected earnings per share for the coming 12 months, up from 16.7 times. Strong guidance would validate the market’s belief that sales and profits can keep growing, keeping stocks moving higher. But anything that causes analysts to reduce profit forecasts could easily cause the stock market to drop.  The good news is that the early signs are positive. In the past three months, more companies have increased earnings guidance than reduced it, according to 22V Research. The gap in increases versus decreases has been near its widest level in about two years. What’s more, S&P 500 companies, in aggregate, expect sales and earnings to rise from quarter to quarter throughout this year. As long as they signal that demand for goods and services is strong enough to support the revenue trends, the stock market will be satisfied, especially since the Federal Reserve doesn’t expect to hike rates any further.  “Management guidance should remain very solid as well, reflecting Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s willingness to let the U.S. economy ‘run hot’ in the months ahead,” writes Wolfe’s Senyek. “As such, we expect trends coming out of 1Q reporting season to provide support for equity markets to keep pushing higher.”  Keep an eye on Constellation Brands, which reports on April 11. Analysts expect the purveyor of wine and beer to report fiscal-year fourth-quarter sales of $2.47 billion and earnings of $3.19 a share. Profits are relatively stable in the alcohol business, where the company’s Modelo beer in particular is doing quite well, and the company has beaten bottom-line estimates in 18 of the past 20 quarters, according to FactSet. A beat and solid guidance could go a long way toward reversing the 4.2% decline the stock has suffered in recent days.  And that would go down like a fine wine—or a bottle of Modelo. Write to Jacob Sonenshine at jacob.sonenshine@barrons.com Signs of improving market breadth, beyond the tech giants, creates opportunities for the new wave of active exchange-traded funds.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Forget Rate Cuts. Here\u2019s What the S.short_description: Forget Rate Cuts. Here’s What the Stock Market Really Needs Now.

Southwest, Boeing Stocks in Focus After.title: Southwest, Boeing Stocks in Focus After Plane Engine Part Detaches on Takeoff
Southwest, Boeing Stocks in Focus After.text:
A 
        Southwest Airlines
       flight had to return to Denver International Airport on Sunday after an engine cowling fell off on takeoff and hit the wing flap, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. The agency said the plane, a 
        Boeing
       737-800, was headed to William P. Hobby Airport in Houston and that it will investigate. Southwest stock was 1% higher in early trading Monday, after falling briefly after the open. Boeing stock was 0.1% up after fluctuating early in the session. Southwest said flight 3695 returned to Denver and landed safely after experiencing a mechanical issue. Passengers traveled to Houston on another aircraft about three hours behind schedule.  “We apologize for the inconvenience of their delay, but place our highest priority on ultimate Safety for our Customers and Employees,” Southwest said in an emailed statement. “Our Maintenance teams are reviewing the aircraft.” A Boeing representative referred requests for comment to Southwest. A cowling is a covering for an engine. The FAA said the aircraft’s crew reported the incident. The 737-800 plane involved in Sunday’s incident is seven years old. This is one of the biggest travel weekends of the spring season, with people moving about the country for spring break and to find a place to watch Monday’s total solar eclipse. The FAA has forecast the number of flights on Sunday to be around 44,200, and the number of flights Monday to climb to 47,100.  Write to Liz Moyer at liz.moyer@barrons.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. FAA to Probe Loss of Engine Cover on Sou.title: FAA to Probe Loss of Engine Cover on Southwest Airlines Boeing Jet -- Update
FAA to Probe Loss of Engine Cover on Sou.text:
By Kimberley Kao The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration is investigating an incident in which an engine cover fell off a Southwest Airlines-flown Boeing 737-800 jet during takeoff from Denver, Colorado, on Sunday. The FAA said Flight 3695, which was headed for Houston, Texas, returned safely to the Denver International Airport around 8:15 a.m. after its crew reported that an engine cover fell off during takeoff and struck a wing flap. The aircraft was towed to the gate upon landing, the FAA said. Southwest said in a statement that maintenance teams were reviewing the aircraft and apologized for the delay. The passengers were moved to another aircraft and were expected to arrive in Houston approximately three hours behind schedule. A Boeing spokesperson referred the request to Southwest for information about the jet and the airline's fleet operations. The 737-800 is a variant of Boeing's 737 Next-Generation aircraft. The incident Sunday is the latest under investigation by the FAA related to engine and other issues of Southwest-operated Boeing planes in recent weeks. Last week, a Southwest Boeing 737 flight bound for Las Vegas was cancelled after an engine caught fire shortly after the plane taxied from the gate at Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport in Texas. Last month, a Southwest Boeing flight from Austin, Texas, turned around mid-flight after its crew reported a possible engine issue, according to the FAA. The crews for two separate Southwest Boeing flights on March 22 reported issues related to a flap and an engine, respectively, the FAA's website shows. Write to Kimberley Kao at kimberley.kao@wsj.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. Spirit Airlines Delays Airbus Deliveries.title: Spirit Airlines Delays Airbus Deliveries to Boost Liquidity. It Could Help Boeing-Exposed Carriers.
Spirit Airlines Delays Airbus Deliveries.text:
Spirit Airlines
       has opted to delay some 
        Airbus
       aircraft deliveries until the beginning of the next decade to boost liquidity. It could help carriers frustrated by 
        Boeing’s
       delays. The ultra-low-cost carrier said Monday it has agreed to defer all aircraft orders scheduled for delivery in the second quarter of 2025 through the end of 2026 until 2030-2031. However, there are no changes to orders set to be delivered in 2027-2029. The deferrals will improve Spirit’s liquidity position by $340 million over the next two years, it said in a filing. The airline also said it will furlough 260 pilots from Sept.1 due the move as well as the grounding of other aircraft through engine-related problems. 
Spirit
       ended 2023 with an all-Airbus fleet of 205 aircraft and firm orders for 99 planes to be delivered through 2029, according to its 10-K annual filing in February. A number of those orders have now been pushed out beyond 2030. That could free up some Airbus aircraft in the coming years, or help carriers take earlier deliveries. Airlines are becoming increasingly frustrated by 
        Boeing’s
       regulatory, production and safety problems—
        United Airlines
       has even asked pilots to take unpaid leave next month as the delivery delays have led to overstaffing as it will now receive fewer planes than expected. 
        Southwest Airlines
       and 
        Ryanair,
       two major Boeing customers, have cut capacity this year. The number of aircraft being deferred isn’t huge—Spirit’s 99 orders were spread evenly over the five years to 2029–but 
        JetBlue
       made a similar move earlier this year in a bid to cut costs. That could offer some scope for carriers to order more Airbus A320s to fill the void left by Boeing’s delays. Airbus stock rose 1.1% in European trading, while Boeing shares pointed 1.2% lower ahead of the U.S. market open Monday. Spirit Airlines reported losses in three of the four quarters last year despite surging travel demand. Wall Street currently expects its two-quarter losing streak to extend through the next eight quarters. The shares were largely being propped up by Spirit’s proposed merger with JetBlue until the deal was blocked by a federal judge, who sided with the Justice Department’s view that it would lead to higher fares. The stock is down 73% in 2024, while JetBlue has climbed 23%. Write to Callum Keown at callum.keown@barrons.com Buying stocks after the “final rate hike” in a cycle demands perfect timing. Spirit Airlines Delays Airbus Deliveries.short_description: Spirit Airlines Delays Airbus Deliveries to Boost Liquidity. It Could Help Boeing-Exposed Carriers.

Engine cover rips off Southwest Airlines.title: Engine cover rips off Southwest Airlines plane, forcing flight to return to Denver
Engine cover rips off Southwest Airlines.text:
DENVER — A Southwest Airlines jet returned to Denver on Sunday morning after the engine cover fell off and struck the wing flap during takeoff, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. The Boeing 737 landed safely, and the passengers headed to Houston were being put onto another aircraft, Southwest Airlines 
        LUV,
        +0.11%
       said in a statement. “We apologize for the inconvenience of their delay, but place our highest priority on ultimate Safety for our Customers and Employees. Our Maintenance teams are reviewing the aircraft,” the statement reads. It’s the second mishap this week for the airline, with a flight from Texas canceled Thursday after a report of an engine fire. The Lubbock, Texas, fire department confirmed online a fire in one of the two engines that needed extinguishing. The FAA is investigating both incidents. Both planes were Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.26%
       737-800s, an older model than the 737 Max. Shares of Southwest were down 1.2% in premarket trading on Monday.  MarketWatch contributed to this report Alphabet shares surge after Google’s parent posts better-than-expected earnings and announces its first cash dividend, Microsoft posts 31% quarterly growth in Azure cloud-computing revenue, and Exxon Mobil’s earnings miss estimates. United States: TotalEnergies Expands its.title: United States: TotalEnergies Expands its Natural Gas Production in Texas
United States: TotalEnergies Expands its.text:
Regulatory News: TotalEnergies (Paris:TTE) (LSE:TTE) (NYSE:TTE) has agreed to acquire the 20% interest held by Lewis Energy Group in the Dorado leases operated by EOG Resources (80%) in the Eagle Ford shale gas play, increasing its natural gas production capacity in Texas and further strengthening its business integration in the U.S. LNG value chain. TotalEnergies increases its natural gas production in the U.S Located in Texas, the Dorado field will allow TotalEnergies to increase its net U.S. natural gas production by 50 million cubic feet a day (Mcf/d) in 2024, with the potential for an additional 50 Mcf/d by 2028. The field has an emission intensity of around 10 kg CO(2) e/boe. In 2023, TotalEnergies' net U.S. natural gas output reached around 340 Mcf/d (450 Mcf/d technical production). TotalEnergies, largest exporter of U.S. LNG With over 10 million tons (Mt) in 2023, TotalEnergies was the number one exporter of U.S. LNG, thanks to its 16.6% stake in the Cameron LNG plant in Louisiana and several long-term purchasing agreements. The Company's LNG export capacity will reach 15 Mt/y by 2030 following the start-up of the first phase of the Rio Grande LNG project in Texas, currently under construction. "This acquisition strengthens our production of natural gas in the United States, contributing to reinforce TotalEnergies' LNG integration with a low cost and low emission upstream gas feed," said Nicolas Terraz, President, Exploration & Production at TotalEnergies. "We are pleased to partner with EOG Resources, an operator recognized for its strong technical expertise." *** TotalEnergies in the United States TotalEnergies is deploying its integrated energy model in the United States, where it has been active since 1957. With over 10 Mt of output in 2023, TotalEnergies is the leading exporter of US LNG, thanks to its 16.6% stake in the Cameron LNG plant in Louisiana and long-term supply contracts. By 2030, this capacity will reach 15 Mt/y, following the start-up of the Rio Grande LNG plant in South Texas. With upstream gas production assets in Texas, the Company is integrated throughout the LNG value chain. The US is a key country for the deployment of TotalEnergies' Integrated Power strategy, where its portfolio includes 25 GW of renewables projects, flexible generation assets, including 1.5 GW of gas-fired power plants in Texas, and a trading center in Houston. The Company is also active in upstream oil production in the Gulf of Mexico, and in refining and petrochemicals, centered on its platform in Port Arthur (Texas). TotalEnergies is also present in CCS and in low-carbon fuels, such as biogas and e-NG. TotalEnergies, the world's third largest LNG player TotalEnergies is the world's third largest LNG player with a global portfolio of 44 Mt/y in 2023 thanks to its interests in liquefaction plants in all geographies. The Company benefits from an integrated position across the LNG value chain, including production, transportation, access to more than 20 Mt/y of regasification capacity in Europe, trading, and LNG bunkering. TotalEnergies' ambition is to increase the share of natural gas in its sales mix to close to 50% by 2030, to reduce carbon emissions and eliminate methane emissions associated with the gas value chain, and to work with local partners to promote the transition from coal to natural gas. About TotalEnergies TotalEnergies is a global integrated energy company that produces and markets energies: oil and biofuels, natural gas and green gases, renewables and electricity. Our more than 100,000 employees are committed to provide as many people as possible with energy that is more reliable, more affordable and more sustainable. Active in about 120 countries, TotalEnergies places sustainability at the heart of its strategy, its projects and its operations. @TotalEnergies l TotalEnergies l TotalEnergies l TotalEnergies Cautionary Note The terms "TotalEnergies", "TotalEnergies company" or "Company" in this document are used to designate TotalEnergies SE and the consolidated entities that are directly or indirectly controlled by TotalEnergies SE. Likewise, the words "we", "us" and "our" may also be used to refer to these entities or to their employees. The entities in which TotalEnergies SE directly or indirectly owns a shareholding are separate legal entities. This document may contain forward-looking information and statements that are based on a number of economic data and assumptions made in a given economic, competitive and regulatory environment. They may prove to be inaccurate in the future and are subject to a number of risk factors. Neither TotalEnergies SE nor any of its subsidiaries assumes any obligation to update publicly any forward-looking information or statement, objectives or trends contained in this document whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. Information concerning risk factors, that may affect TotalEnergies' financial results or activities is provided in the most recent Universal Registration Document, the French-language version of which is filed by TotalEnergies SE with the French securities regulator Autorité des Marchés Financiers (AMF), and in the Form 20-F filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Boeing Adds Safety Goals for CEO After R.title: Boeing Adds Safety Goals for CEO After Record 2023 Pay
Boeing Adds Safety Goals for CEO After R.text:
Boeing
       CEO Dave Calhoun took home $32.8 million in pay for 2023, up 45% compared with the $22.5 million earned in 2022. Last year was a good one for the company, but 2024 hasn’t started out as well.  Boeing filed its annual proxy statement on Friday evening, including a summary of compensation for major executives. Calhoun’s pay includes $1.4 million in salary and $30.2 million in stock awards. Other compensation makes up the balance.  It was the highest annual pay for a Boeing CEO this century, company filings show, despite Calhoun declining a $2.8 million bonus.  Some of the $30.2 million is performance-based pay, which is set according to a variety of financial metrics. One is free cash flow, which took off last year, rising to $4.4 billion from $2 billion in 2022.   Free cash flow in 2024 is expected to fall as the company deals with the aftermath of the 737 MAX 9 emergency-door-plug blowout on Jan. 5. The incident has led to more oversight by the Federal Aviation Administration; more costs for Boeing, such as compensation paid to airline customers for missed deliveries and lost capacity to handle passengers; and slower production of MAX jets.  Boeing said Calhoun’s 2024 performance-based compensation target would be reduced to $13.25 million from $17 million. The target performance pay is essentially what is earned if things go as expected. The final pay awarded can move higher or lower depending on how the company, and its CEO, do relative to the goals set by the board of directors.   Boeing added that it will link Calhoun’s2024 compensation to two new safety and production quality goals. Part of one goal includes the “design and deployment of an employee culture survey,” The second goal includes the “development and implementation of operational control limits for several programs, including the 737 program.”  More than 50% of the 2024 performance award is tied to the two goals.  This is Calhoun’s final year as CEO. He announced his departure in March without the board naming a successor. The search is on for the next CEO.  Company filings show Calhoun made a bit less than $100 million between 2020 and 2023 running the company. Boeing stock was at about $330 a share when he took over; shares closed at $183.14 on Friday.  The stock is down about 30% so far this year, making it the fifth-worst-performing stock in the 
        S&P 500.
       Most of the declines came after the door blowout.   Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Tesla stock has risen for three consecutive days, after falling for seven straight.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Boeing Adds Safety Goals for CEO After R.short_description: Boeing Adds Safety Goals for CEO After Record 2023 Pay

These stocks\u2019 price targets have be.title: These stocks’ price targets have been cut the most by Wall Street analysts in 2024
These stocks\u2019 price targets have be.text:
In an orderly world, companies would increase revenue and profits steadily to support a continual lifting of earnings estimates and price targets for stocks. But life is never simple. The general trend is for the stock market as a whole to rise along with corporate profits, but there are always exceptions, and these can help investors understand what to avoid — and where new opportunities may lie. Last week we looked back at how the favorite stocks among analysts who work for brokerage firms had performed over the past five years. It turned out that the brokers had fared pretty well.  Today we will look at current consensus price targets for stocks among analysts polled by FactSet, and we’ll list the companies for which the targets have declined the most since the end of last year.  The analysts tend to specialize in particular sectors or industries. They assign the equivalent of buy, hold or sell ratings to stocks, along with price targets that are typically meant to cover the next 12 months. The ratings have a positive skew. There are relatively few sell or equivalent ratings, in part because analysts might believe bad news for a company is already baked into its share price. It might be too late to drop to a sell rating after bad news has been reported.  Among the S&P 500 
        SPX,
       53% of companies have majority buy ratings, and only one company has majority sell ratings: Expeditors International of Washington Inc. 
        EXPD,
        +0.74%.
 Getting back to what analysts and investors want to see, so far this year consensus price targets have increased for 80% of the S&P 500. If you are wondering how many of these 402 stocks have risen in price this year, the answer is 320, or 80%.  Now let’s screen the S&P 500 for the companies whose consensus price targets have declined the most this year through Monday, according to data provided by FactSet: For Tesla Inc. 
        TSLA,
        -1.53%,
       the consensus price target has declined 16.9% this year, while the share price has gone down 29.5% through Monday. Sometimes an analyst will stick with a buy rating but lower their price target as a stock falls. Wedbush analyst Dan Ives has taken a strong bullish stance for Tesla for a long time, but last week he cut his price target for the stock to $300 from $315 and described a “white-knuckle period” for the company. There are 51 analysts polled by FactSet who are covering Tesla, and a third of them rate the stock a buy or the equivalent, while 20% rate it a sell or the equivalent, and the rest have neutral ratings on the shares. Ives and two other analysts have $300 price targets for the stock — the highest among the analysts. The consensus price target for Tesla is $200.39, and the stock closed at $175.22 Monday. News early Tuesday: Tesla’s stock slumps as delivery numbers miss the mark by a wide margin Humana Inc. 
        HUM,
        -1.10%
       leads the list with the largest consensus-price-target decline among the S&P 500 this year. The company is among several managed-care providers that are focused on Medicare Advantage plans. The problem has been a lower-than-expected payout rate by Medicare. Michael Taylor, the lead portfolio manager for the Simplify Health Care exchange-traded fund 
        PINK,
       highlighted Cigna Group 
        CI,
        +0.05%
       as standing out among managed-care companies in the S&P 500, since it mainly provides service through employer-sponsored health-insurance plans. Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. 
        WBD,
        -1.69%
       is an interesting case that signals the need for more data. The consensus price target for the stock has declined 15.5% this year, while the share price has fallen 22.8%. The target price of $13.21 is 50% higher than Monday’s closing price of $8.79. And 17 of 31 analysts polled by FactSet rate the stock a buy or the equivalent. Leaving the list in the same order, here is a summary of analysts’ opinions about the stocks: Some notes about the data: Click on the tickers for more about each company. Click here for Tomi Kilgore’s detailed guide to the wealth of information available for free on the MarketWatch quote page. Don’t miss: Outperforming ETF manager names a potential ‘50-bagger’ in the stock market Tesla stock has risen for three consecutive days, after falling for seven straight.  Philip van Doorn writes the Deep Dive investing column for MarketWatch. Follow him on Twitter @PhilipvanDoorn. Philip van Doorn writes the Deep Dive investing column for MarketWatch. American Express, Schlumberger, and Rivi.title: American Express, Schlumberger, and Rivian Stock Could Climb, Analysts Say
American Express, Schlumberger, and Rivi.text:
These reports, excerpted and edited by Barron’s, were issued recently by investment and research firms. The reports are a sampling of analysts’ thinking; they should not be considered the views or recommendations of Barron’s. Some of the reports’ issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed. 
American Express
       • AXP-NYSE
		
			
		
	Buy • Price $219.59 on April 5
		
			
		
	by Monness, Crespi, Hardt
		
			
		
	We are getting off the sidelines and upgrading American Express to a Buy with a $245 price target on our calendar-2024 earnings-per-share estimate of $13.16 (versus consensus $12.81). Year-to-date performance for AmEx/S&P 500, respectively, is +18%/+9.8%.  We like the setup after the sell-off yesterday [April 4] and going into the first-quarter print at 16.5 times our calendar-2024 price/earnings. We also like the potential for positive revisions to medium-term guidance during its investor day on April 30. In the near term, we underestimated AmEx’s resiliency, owing to its higher-end consumer; spend/lend levels of customers set the company up well should macro softness materialize. 
Schlumberger
       • SLB-NYSE
		
			
		
	Buy • Price $55.22 on April 2
		
			
		
	by Jefferies
		
			
		
	Schlumberger agreed to acquire 
        ChampionX
       in an all-stock transaction for $7.75 billion, strengthening its core business while progressing on its returns-focused and capital-light strategy.  ChampionX is primarily involved in providing production chemicals and artificial lift technologies, positioning Schlumberger to increasingly participate in the efficiency improvement/reservoir recovery phase of upstream operations.  We believe the transaction should be favorably received, considering it increases Schlumberger’s exposure to less cyclical/less capital-intensive production business while being accretive to Ebitda margins. The complementary nature of Schlumberger’s and ChampionX’s businesses should allow the company to accomplish the target cost synergies. Target price: $71. 
Rivian
       • RIVN-Nasdaq
		
			
		
	Outperform • Price $11.09 on April 2
		
			
		
	by Baird
		
			
		
	Rivian reported first-quarter production and delivery numbers that beat our/consensus estimates and reaffirmed production guidance of 57,000 vehicles for full-year 2024. It has been well communicated by management that the second and third quarters will be impacted by factory downtime associated with rerating, and we model the biggest impact in the second quarter. With the R2 [midsize sport-utility vehicle] reveal in the rearview, we expect attention will shift to cost reductions and Rivian’s goal to reach positive gross profit per unit in fourth-quarter 2024.  The fourth-quarter 2023 shareholder letter outlined areas for cost reductions that include 50% from variable costs (design changes, supplier negotiations, raw material costs); 35% fixed cost efficiencies; and 15% in nonvehicle revenue (service, accessories, insurance, etc). Price target: $23. 
Moderna
       • MRNA-Nasdaq
		
			
		
	Outperform • Price $105.60 on April 2
		
			
		
	by Oppenheimer
		
			
		
	Moderna hosted its fifth annual Vaccines Day on March 27. The company provided an update to its latent, respiratory, and other portfolio and to its commercial and financial framework. The portfolio of latent vaccines is advancing into pivotal development after successes in early-stage trials.  For respiratory viruses, Moderna shared a positive interim Phase 3 update from its next-generation, refrigerator-stable mRNA vaccine. Its design offers the potential of longer shelf life and storage advantages, also advantageous for the combination vaccine against influenza/Covid-19.  Flu regulatory filings are planned this year; Moderna strengthened its prospects with the Blackstone deal [for collaboration with Moderna’s influenza program]. Price target: $142. 
DoorDash
       • DASH-Nasdaq
		
			
		
	Buy • Price $138.78 on April 4
		
			
		
	by Benchmark
		
			
		
	Our Buy rating is rooted in DoorDash’s ever-growing dominance in restaurant delivery and the subsequent network effects that its massive user/driver scale afford it to new retail vectors, including grocery, convenience, and bricks-and-mortar broadly.  We expect monetization potential of these emerging verticals to become more tangible over the next 12-plus months, leading to greater velocity of revenue and contribution margin that is not contemplated in our or consensus expectations.  We value the shares at $165 using a discounted cash flow analysis. 
Signet Jewelers
       • SIG-Nasdaq
		
			
		
	Buy • Price $104.43 on April 4
		
			
		
	by 
        UBS

		
	We believe Signet Jeweler’s self-help initiatives should lead to sustained sales outperformance, especially as its bridal business turns. Importantly, the company’s early convertible shares repurchase announcement reinforces our view that Signet has several levers to deliver solid long-term EPS growth.  We forecast a 13% five-year EPS compound annual growth and expect EPS beats over the next 12 months to catalyze the stock toward our new, $152 price target. 
Intuitive Machines
       • LUNR-Nasdaq
		
			
		
	Buy • Price $5.98 on April 4
		
			
		
	by Canaccord Genuity
		
			
		
	NASA announced that it has selected Intuitive Machines to lead a team of contractors developing the Lunar Terrain Vehicle, or LTV, which is the modern version of the “Moon Buggy,” or Lunar Roving Vehicle, from the Apollo program. The new platform, dubbed the “Moon Racer,” will be constructed by Intuitive’s consortium, which includes partners like 
        Boeing,
       Michelin, 
        Northrop Grumman,
       and AVL.  We have adjusted our revenue and gross margin estimates in 2024 and 2025 to reflect the new LTV contract award. Price target: $14. Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun\u2019s pay climb.title: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun’s pay climbed 45% last year
Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun\u2019s pay climb.text:
Dave Calhoun, the outgoing chief executive of troubled aerospace giant Boeing Co., saw his total compensation climb last year by 45%, to $32.8 million, according to a filing Friday. Much of Calhoun’s salary increase was driven by a retention bonus intended to keep him in the top job at Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.33%
       through 2025. But he also gave up a roughly $3 million cash bonus and is receiving less stock this year following a high-profile aircraft accident in January that has thrown Boeing’s 737 Max program into disarray. Calhoun’s 2023 compensation included $1.4 million in salary plus equity awards valued at $30.2 million. His pay totaled $22.6 million in 2022, including $17 million in stock and options.  Boeing’s share price rose almost 29% last year, but is down about 30% so far in 2024. Boeing’s board recently said that Calhoun would step down by year-end and that it was searching for a new boss. A door-plug blowout on an Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.35%
       flight in January has led to federal probes and slowed down production lines. Calhoun, who turns 67 later this month, became CEO in January 2020. The NBA and other major sports leagues make millions from legalized gambling. It could end up costing them. Jon Swartz is a senior reporter for MarketWatch in San Francisco, covering many of the biggest players in tech, including Netflix, Facebook and Google. Jon has covered technology for more than 20 years, and previously worked for Barron's and USA Today. Follow him on Twitter @jswartz. Be Wary of Spirit AeroSystems Stock. The.title: Be Wary of Spirit AeroSystems Stock. There’s a Russell Wilson Problem.
Be Wary of Spirit AeroSystems Stock. The.text:
What to do with shares of 
        Spirit AeroSystems
       is a tricky question for investors to answer. While 
        Boeing
       will likely take over the company, the price it will pay is nearly impossible to predict.  Investors should err on the side of caution.  The issue isn’t whether a deal will happen. Boeing and Spirit Aero, its fuselage supplier, confirmed that they were in merger talks about a month ago. Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun answered, “I hope soon” on March 25 in response to a question about when a deal could be done. More recently, reports about a deal to sell the part of Spirit that makes components for 
        Airbus
       have surfaced.   Boeing declined to comment. Spirit Aero didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.  The valuation issue is difficult. Wall Street’s targets for Spirit stock range from $28 to $42, while the shares were at just under $35 in early trading on Friday. That is up from roughly $29 before news of the merger talks boosted the price.   At $35 a share, Spirit Aero is trading for about 17 times the per-share earnings expected for 2025. The 
        S&P 500
       trades for closer to 19 times.  Two arguments for a higher price are that Spirit’s margins are expected to improve in coming years. And companies typically pay a premium in takeovers, reflecting savings or other benefits the deals are expected to achieve.  The cost savings in a merger between Spirit and Boeing could easily amount to $100 million to $200 million a year. Including those savings, Spirit might sell for higher than even the Street’s most optimistic call of $42 a share.  The Airbus business is what complicates matters. While it accounted for almost 20% of Spirit’s 2023 sales, it has to be sold. There is no way Boeing can keep Airbus as a customer.   The problem is that the business isn’t big enough to operate efficiently. Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard wrote Friday that the Spirit plants supplying Airbus needed significant investment—as much as $1 billion—to perform up to snuff.  No one is going to pay a lot for the Airbus business if they have to invest $1 billion. It is a lot of money, considering that Spirit’s market capitalization is about $4 billion.  The problem for Boeing and Spirit is a little like what happens to NFL or MLB teams looking to unload players under expensive contracts. This year, the Denver Broncos released quarterback Russell Wilson two years into a five-year, $245 million contract. They couldn’t find anyone to trade for that contract.  Last year, the New York Mets got the Texas Rangers to agree to take Max Scherzer, partly by paying roughly $35 million of the remaining $58 million due to the player. The Mets got a minor-league prospect in return.  Both players were valuable assets that required a lot of investment, making them less appealing to other teams. “That could be the situation here,” said Stallard when asked about selling the Airbus business.  He isn’t bullish on Spirit Aero. He rates the stock at Hold with a target of $31 for the price. While a takeover is likely, the party getting the best deal will probably be the one buying the Airbus business.   Spirit Aero stock was up 2.1% in early trading at $34.74 a share while the 
        S&P 500
       and 
        Nasdaq Composite
       were up 0.6% and 1%, respectively. Boeing shares are up 0.2%.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Oversold rally earlier this week doesn’t erase the U.S.  market’s negative picture. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Be Wary of Spirit AeroSystems Stock. The.short_description: Be Wary of Spirit AeroSystems Stock. There’s a Russell Wilson Problem.

This bank is still paying 6.17% on its s.title: This bank is still paying 6.17% on its savings account — and 9 more of the best-paying savings accounts you can get in April 2024
This bank is still paying 6.17% on its s.text: MarketWatch Picks highlights items we think you’ll find useful; the MarketWatch News staff is not involved in creating this content. We might earn a commission from links in this content. Learn more Most Americans are not earning as much as they could on their savings,  with 67% of savers getting less than 4%, according to Bankrate’s latest savings report. This despite plenty of savings accounts paying over 5% (see some of the higher paying savings accounts you can get now here) — and “despite widespread availability of higher returns on federally-insured accounts with little or no minimum deposit required,” says Greg McBride, chief financial analyst at Bankrate. While traditional savings accounts often pay very low interest rates, high-yield savings accounts (HYSAs) typically earn much higher rates. Usually, like traditional savings accounts, they tend to come with minimal risk (most are FDIC or NCUA-insured up to $250,000) and flexible options like being able to transfer or withdraw funds at no cost.  This can make them a smart place to park cash that you need easily accessible, like an emergency fund, pros say. “Many financial advisers recommend keeping an emergency fund of 3 to 6 months’ worth of expenses in a safe investment such as a high-yield savings account, but there are many factors that should be considered,” says certified financial planner Alison James at WorthWise Financial Partners. “How stable is your employment? Are there one or two earners in the family? Are there dependents? What percentage of expenses are discretionary versus fixed?.”  (See some of the higher paying savings accounts you can get now here) Paying attention to interest rates on your high-yield savings account is key as they affect how much you earn. That said, you’ll also want to be sure you understand any restrictions or fees associated with the accounts you’re opening. “Change banks to wipe away useless overdraft and account maintenance fees – and switch savings to earn more interest back on your money with a competitive annual percentage yield,” says consumer savings expert Andrea Woroch.  Here are the highest-paying savings accounts we found this month. Note that some of the credit unions have strict membership rules, but other banks on this list offer the high APYs without as many hoops to jump through. Those who live, work, go to school in Washington State or are affiliated with Boeing are eligible for membership. Members who open a savings account aren’t subject to monthly maintenance fees or minimum balance requirements. They can also earn a premium rate of 6.17% — but the big catch is that it’s only on the first $500 deposited. To qualify for this offer, members must have both a BECU checking and savings account, sign up to receive monthly eStatements and make at least one free electronic transaction per month. It’s now possible to earn 5.75% APY on new account deposits up to $1,000, or you can earn a lofty 5.61% on balances $1,000.01 and higher. Whether you’re a member of the military or one of Andrews’ select employee groups across Maryland, Washington DC, Virginia and New Jersey, accounts opened through online or mobile banking qualify for this tiered, variable rate account. BrioDirect is part of the FDIC-insured institution Webster Bank, and the account has no monthly maintenance fee. The catch? You must deposit a minimum of $5,000 to open an account. Open an account with just $500 and earn 5.35% with no monthly account fees. Boeing MAX Production Is at a Crawl. It.title: Boeing MAX Production Is at a Crawl. It Would Take 20 Years to Fill the Backlog at This Rate.
Boeing MAX Production Is at a Crawl. It.text:
Boeing’s
       737 MAX production has slowed to a crawl. That’s probably a good thing though airline customers might not agree. Boeing suppliers, on the other hand, should be all right—if 
        Boeing
       can get its act together.  Boeing’s targeted and Federal Aviation Administration-permitted MAX production rate is currently 38 a month. The company delivered 42 MAX jets in January and February. Boeing will report March deliveries in a few days. Investors shouldn’t expect a big number.  “Cirium data shows that Boeing only test flew 13 MAX planes in March, similar to the 11 that it flew in February,” wrote Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard in a report Thursday. Cirium is an aviation consultancy used by the industry and Wall Street.  All signs point to another month of around 20 MAX deliveries. Along with new production, Boeing is still delivering MAX jets built and parked during the worldwide MAX grounding between March 2019 and November 2020 following two deadly crashes within five months.  Melius analyst Robert Spingarn believes the first-quarter production rate will end up lower than 20 per month. There is a good reason for lower production. Boeing is working “to minimize traveled work,” wrote the analyst in a report Friday. Traveled work refers to doing jobs on the production line somewhere other than originally designed. Less travel work is a sign Boeing is trying to get its production system under better control. That change came in the aftermath of the early January emergency door plug blowout on a 737 MAX 9 operated by 
        Alaska Air.
 More control and better quality is a positive, but it does put short-term and long-term estimates at risk. Wall Street expects Boeing to deliver about 450 MAX jets in 2024, up from 387 delivered in 2023. In the long term, Boeing expects to produce 50 MAX jets a month. “Given the current state of the 737 ramp, Boeing’s targeted rate of 50/month in 2025/2026 seems unlikely,” added Spingarn.  Boeing has some 4,800 unfilled orders for 737 MAX jets. At 20 a month, that’s 20 years of backlog. It’s great to have a big backlog but Boeing’s airline customers would balk. Things should improve, still, at 40 a month Boeing has 10 years of backlog and some airlines would be waiting longer than expected for new jets.  That has some implications for Boeing as well as the airlines. Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu noted in a report that Boeing paid Alaska $160 million in compensation for the MAX 9 grounding and lost airline capacity. Extrapolating that payment to other airlines lacking MAX capacity is difficult—only one door plug blew off—but she expects Boeing to report more than $420 million payments to airlines for the first quarter. Boeing “expects additional compensation to be provided beyond Q1, the terms of which are confidential,” added the analyst.  The production delays make life harder for the airlines and Boeing. There will eventually be an impact on suppliers too. 
        Spirit AeroSystems
       and 
        Hexcel
       are two at the biggest risk of estimate cuts, Kahyaoglu wrote. Both companies’ estimates imply production rates closer to 38 a month; she now expects an average of about 30 MAX jets made a month in 2024.    Boeing can still take parts at a higher rate than it is making planes, but investors should, at least, be aware of the potential for cuts given how the year has started.  At 30 a month, it would take Boeing some 13 years to work through its existing MAX backlog. Production rates shouldn’t stay at that level forever. Still, the entire aerospace value chain—from suppliers to airlines—is waiting for things to improve.  Boeing stock was up 0.4% in premarket trading Friday, while 
        S&P 500
       and 
        Dow Jones Industrial Average
       futures rose 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively.  Coming into Friday trading, Boeing stock has fallen about 30% this year. MAX troubles have weighed on investor sentiment.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Tech stocks launched a solid rebound early Friday as Alphabet and Microsoft earnings brought renewed optimism to the sector. Boeing MAX Production Is at a Crawl. It.short_description: Boeing MAX Production Is at a Crawl. It Would Take 20 Years to Fill the Backlog at This Rate.

Europe Is Itching to Cut Interest Rates,.title: Europe Is Itching to Cut Interest Rates, Unlike the Fed. Why It Matters.
Europe Is Itching to Cut Interest Rates,.text: While Federal Reserve officials say they are in no rush to cut interest rates, central bankers in Europe seem eager to get the rate-cutting started. There are good reasons for U.S. investors to pay attention: If European central banks cut rates sooner and more aggressively than the Fed, that could reinforce the dollar’s strength.  The Dollar Index, a measure of the dollar’s value against the currencies of most of the U.S.’s key trading partners, has already gained 3.5% this year. A higher dollar diminishes the value of overseas sales of U.S. companies, though it could make Europe a cheaper destination for U.S. tourists. The Bank of England, which sets rates for the United Kingdom, and the European Central Bank, which sets policy for the 20 countries sharing the euro, including Germany and France, are currently expected to cut rates around the same time as the Fed. But there are increasing signs that Europe is itching to start sooner. For one, inflation rates are still falling quickly in the U.K. and the euro zone, whereas in the U.S., the Fed’s preferred inflation gauge suggests that price growth looks sticky. Second, some policymakers in Europe are becoming more vocal about pushing for earlier moves. And third, the economic outlook is much weaker across the pond, providing an extra incentive for central banks to lend support for growth. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell says he’s in no hurry to cut interest rates. The personal-consumption expenditures index, the Fed’s preferred inflation metric, showed a 2.8% annual gain in March, in line with expectations and well above the Fed’s 2% annual inflation target. Economists and investors expect the first Fed cut in June, although the risks seem skewed toward a longer wait. Compare those views to the latest remarks from Bank of England Gov. Andrew Bailey, who told the Financial Times just after the March rate decision that progress on inflation means rate cuts are a possibility at every meeting henceforth. While the two most hawkish members of the rate-setting committee pushed back against Bailey’s comments, they also took a dovish turn—voting to keep rates steady in March after having called for further hikes. With the U.K.’s inflation rate dropping to 3.4% in February from 4% in January, and forecasts calling for it to fall to the 2% target this quarter, one BOE committee member is already voting for cuts. The U.K. economy is emerging from a recession. Economists still see the first rate cut as most likely in August, but markets are pricing in a chance of a cut at the May meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde won’t commit to a path of cuts but has teed up June as a likely start date. Her colleague, Bank of France Gov. François Villeroy de Galhau, has hinted at a cut as soon as the next meeting, on April 11. Euro zone inflation dropped to 2.4% in March from 2.6% in February. Last month, the Swiss National Bank surprised markets by cutting rates. It’s the first major central bank to lower borrowing costs since the end of the Covid pandemic. Policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic have become more skeptical about their inflation forecasts. In January, Lagarde lambasted her economists for being too myopic in failing to account for the risks of, say, a pandemic or Russia invading Ukraine.  The BOE, meanwhile, has commissioned former Fed Chairman and Nobel Prize winner Ben Bernanke to write a report on how to improve its forecasting. It is due to be published this month. If officials don’t trust forecasts for inflation, it could lead them to keep rates higher than otherwise—or worry that rates are too high, given the economic conditions. That gives more scope for central bank policies to diverge, with greater consequences for markets.  Write to Brian Swint at brian.swint@barrons.com Signs of improving market breadth, beyond the tech giants, creates opportunities for the new wave of active exchange-traded funds.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Europe Is Itching to Cut Interest Rates,.short_description: Europe Is Itching to Cut Interest Rates, Unlike the Fed. Why It Matters.

Alaska Air was paid $160 million in cash.title: Alaska Air was paid $160 million in cash by Boeing for the 737 Max 9 issues
Alaska Air was paid $160 million in cash.text:
Alaska Air Group Inc. said it lost more in the first quarter than it previously estimated, but only because it changed how it recorded cash received from Boeing Co. as compensation for losses suffered from the groundings of 737 Max 9 jets. The air carrier’s stock 
        ALK,
        -1.30%
       rose 1.7% in morning trading, while Boeing shares 
        BA,
        +0.32%
       tacked on 1%. The air carrier estimates that a door-panel blowout in January and the subsequent plane groundings cost the company $160 million, primarily in lost revenue and other costs due to irregular operations. As a result, Alaska Air said it was paid $160 million in cash by Boeing during the first quarter. The company expects to receive additional compensation in future quarters, the terms of which are confidential. Alaska Air said the cash compensation was initially booked as earnings. But after further review of accounting standards and industry precedence, the compensation is now being accounted as a reduction to aircraft assets. Therefore, the company now expects an adjusted per-share loss of $1.15 to $1.05 for the first quarter, compared with a previous loss estimate of 55 cents to 45 cents and the FactSet loss consensus of 86 cents.  Alaska Air’s stock has gained 9% year to date, while Boeing shares have tumbled 28.4% and the S&P 500 
        SPX,
        +1.24%
       has advanced 10.1%. Tesla stock has risen for three consecutive days, after falling for seven straight.  Tomi Kilgore is MarketWatch's deputy investing and corporate news editor and is based in New York. You can follow him on Twitter @TomiKilgore. GE Aerospace Stock Picks Up a Buy Rating.title: GE Aerospace Stock Picks Up a Buy Rating. Why It Can Keep Flying.
GE Aerospace Stock Picks Up a Buy Rating.text:
GE Aerospace
       is a premier player in commercial aviation. One analyst is bullish on the stock after the spinoff of the power-generation assets as 
        GE Vernova.
 The Vernova separation was completed on Tuesday. On Thursday, Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard launched coverage of the standalone aerospace company’s stock with a Buy rating and $160 price target.  “While the stock has been on a tear over the last year…we think it is still the most appealing of the three mega-cap U.S. aerospace names,” Stallard wrote in a report. “It has the largest and highest-quality exposure to the aerospace aftermarket, which we estimate generates about 80% of operating profit. Whilst there is still some non-core baggage and the valuation is lofty, we think the stock can still work from here.”  Its jet engines power roughly three out of four commercial flights globally. Engine sellers, including GE, make more on parts and service than they do selling the original equipment to the likes of 
        Boeing
       and 
        Airbus.
 GE Aero stock has certainly taken off; adjusted for the spin, it’s up about 90% over the past 12 months coming into Thursday trading. Stallard’s target works out to about 33 times his estimated 2025 adjusted earnings per share of $4.62. The 
        S&P 500
       trades for less than 20 times 2025 earnings, but Stallard expects GE Aero earnings to grow at about 19% a year for the coming few years. S&P 500 earnings have grown at less than half that rate in recent years.  GE Aero stock is up 0.4% to $146.25 in premarket trading Thursday while S&P 500 and 
        Nasdaq Composite
       futures are up 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. GE Aero stock gained 6.7% on Wednesday—its second day as an independent company. Wall Street deserved some credit for that move.   With the Aero/Vernova separation complete, analysts are updating numbers and price targets for the aerospace company. On Wednesday, Barclays and Deutsche Bank updated their price targets to $175 and $190, respectively. Not all Street price targets have been adjusted for the spin, according to FactSet. The average of a handful of new targets reviewed by Barron’s is roughly $165, up some 13% from recent levels.  More updates will be coming. The early updates show that Wall Street still likes shares of GE Aero. Most of the analysts updating numbers have Buy ratings. Just before the spin, 68% of analysts covering GE stock rated shares at Buy. The average Buy-rating ratio for stocks in the S&P 500 is about 55%.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Buying stocks after the “final rate hike” in a cycle demands perfect timing. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
GE Aerospace Stock Picks Up a Buy Rating.short_description: GE Aerospace Stock Picks Up a Buy Rating. Why It Can Keep Flying.

Intuitive Machines\u2019 stock surges, b.title: Intuitive Machines’ stock surges, boosted by $30 million NASA lunar rover contract
Intuitive Machines\u2019 stock surges, b.text:
Shares of Intuitive Machines Inc. rose 11.2% in premarket trades Thursday after NASA awarded the space-exploration company at $30 million contract to complete a feasibility roadmap for a Lunar Terrain Vehicle using the company’s Nova-D lunar lander.  Intuitive Machines 
        LUNR,
        -0.34%
       is partnering with technology company AVL, Boeing Co. 
        BA,
        +0.31%,
       Michelin 
        ML,
        -0.61%
MGDDY,
        -1.19%,
       and Northrop Grumman Corp. 
        NOC,
        -1.02%
       to develop the Reusable Autonomous Crewed Exploration Rover (RACER). The space company is the prime contractor in the effort to develop RACER. “This is the precursor contract to the Lunar Terrain Vehicle (LTV) $4.6B project for transport services on the Moon,” Benchmark analyst Josh Sullivan wrote in a note released Thursday. “LTV will be a marquee lunar infrastructure award as the vehicle transport services for the $93B Artemis program.” Related: Intuitive Machines says Odysseus has ‘permanently faded’ on the moon, but is planning another mission this year LTV also allows the contractor to sell lunar transport to commercial third parties as well — increasing the commercial value of the contract — according to Sullivan, who described the deal as “Uber for the Moon.” NASA’s Artemis program plans to establish a long-term human presence on the lunar surface, and aims to harness water ice for life support and fuel. Intuitive Machines’ IM-1 mission made history earlier this year when Odysseus became the first commercial lander to successfully land on the lunar surface. Odysseus reached the lunar surface on Feb. 22, sending the company’s stock soaring. Last month Intuitive Machines said that the lander has “permanently faded” and has no chance of waking up on the moon. Related: Odysseus has ‘fundamentally changed the economics of landing on the moon,’ says Intuitive Machines “LUNR’s recent IM-1 landing on the Moon, despite challenges, provides the company a proven lunar flight heritage which competitors lack and benefits future contract evaluations,” wrote Benchmark’s Sullivan. “Further, LUNR has two additional IM missions back to the Moon coming up, and is bidding on IM-4 in 2Q24.” Intuitive Machines shares have risen 134.1% in the last 12 months, outpacing the S&P 500 index’s 
        SPX
       gain of 27%.     Southwest Airlines Co.’s stock tumbled 9% Thursday after the airline posted a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and revenue that lagged estimates. James Rogers is a Financial Columnist for MarketWatch. James Rogers is a Financial Columnist for MarketWatch. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Intuitive Machines\u2019 stock surges, b.short_description: Intuitive Machines’ stock surges, boosted by $30 million NASA lunar rover contract

U.K. Businesses Expect Wage Rises to Slo.title: U.K. Businesses Expect Wage Rises to Slow, BOE Survey Shows
U.K. Businesses Expect Wage Rises to Slo.text:
By Paul Hannon U.K. businesses expect wages to rise at a slower pace over the coming 12 months, a finding that will help reassure policy makers at the Bank of England that inflation has been tamed. A survey of 2,422 businesses carried out by the BOE during March found that the average expected rise in wages eased to 4.9% from 5.2% in February. Those businesses reported that wages were 6.4% higher in the three months through March than in the same period a year earlier. Policy makers have highlighted the strength of recent wage growth as a key concern as they prepare to lower borrowing costs later this year. While the U.K.'s annual rate of consumer-price inflation is expected to hit the BOE's target of 2% during this quarter, that is largely due to a decline in home energy prices. Policy makers worry that after energy prices stabilize, rapidly rising wages could lead to a fresh pickup in inflation. Outgoing Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun Will Ex.title: Outgoing Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun Will Exit Caterpillar Board
Outgoing Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun Will Ex.text:
By Will Feuer Caterpillar said Dave Calhoun, a current board member and the departing chief executive of embattled plane-maker Boeing, will not stand for re-election to Caterpillar's board. Caterpillar said Calhoun's decision to depart from the board isn't the result of any disagreement. The Caterpillar board said it is grateful for Calhoun's service. Boeing said last month that Calhoun, who turns 67 this month, will leave the company at the end of this year, part of a broader executive shake-up at Boeing after a Jan. 5 midair blowout and sweeping production problems that have angered airlines and regulators. Calhoun has been on the board of Caterpillar, a construction-equipment manufacturer, since 2011. Write to Will Feuer at Will.Feuer@wsj.com Why value stocks with low P/E ratios deliver long-term. Ryanair Cancelled Nearly 1,000 Flights i.title: Ryanair Cancelled Nearly 1,000 Flights in March Due to Israel-Hamas War -- Update
Ryanair Cancelled Nearly 1,000 Flights i.text:
By Anthony O. Goriainoff Ryanair Holdings said that it cancelled almost 950 flights in March due to disruption from the Israel-Hamas war, as the conflict continues to hit the airline's operations in the region. The Irish budget airline said Wednesday that it operated more than 77,000 flights in March, with passenger numbers up 8% on year to 13.6 million. Its load factor--a measure of how full a plane is--was flat at 93%. The airline has now cancelled around 5,430 flights since Hamas's Oct. 7 attack and operated more than 447,300. While the Israel-Hamas war has weighed on other airlines' operations in the region, it is rare for carriers to quantify the impact. A notable exception was Air France-KLM, which in February said that geopolitical turmoil in the Middle East and Africa, where a number of countries experienced military coups, had wiped out 65 million euros ($70 million) from its operating result in the fourth quarter. Ryanair has carried 183.7 million passengers over the 12 months to the end of March compared with 168.6 million for the comparable period a year earlier, and slightly more than its previous forecast of 183.5 million. It expects to make a post-tax profit for the year ended March 31, 2024, of between EUR1.85 billion to EUR1.95 billion. However it has previously said these forecasts are dependent upon avoiding adverse events such as the Ukraine war, the Israel-Hamas conflict and further Boeing delivery delays. Shares at 0805 GMT are up 24 European cents, or 1.2%, at EUR20.77. They are currently up 43% over the past 12 months. Separately, eastern Europe-focused budget airline Wizz Air Holdings reported a 12% rise in passengers for March and said that it has restarted operations to Tel-Aviv, Israel, from six bases. It plans further routes to resume throughout April, May and June. Write to Anthony O. This Is Why You Don\u2019t Wait. Next Bo.title: This Is Why You Don’t Wait. Next Boeing Plane Could Cost $50 Billion.
This Is Why You Don\u2019t Wait. Next Bo.text:
Boeing
       has put off designing an all-new, clean-sheet, single-aisle jet for a long, long time. The longer the company waits, the costlier the proposition becomes.  Boeing has its reasons. It has had a lot to deal with in recent years.  The 737 MAX jet—modified from earlier 737 designs—was grounded worldwide between March 2019 and November 2020, following two deadly crashes within five months. On Jan. 5 of this year, an emergency door plug blew out of a 737 MAX 9 jet operated by 
        Alaska Air.
       The incident shook confidence in Boeing’s manufacturing quality, leading to more oversight from the Federal Aviation Administration.  Another reason is cost. CEO Dave Calhoun estimates a new Boeing plane will cost $50 billion to develop. That money gets spent over, perhaps, a decade, but it is still a huge sum for the struggling company.  Through the MAX turmoil, Boeing has added some $40 billion in long-term debt. Annual free cash flow isn’t expected to hit $10 billion until 2026 or 2027. Fixing current problems, including the balance sheet, before designing a new plan is a justifiable position for the company to take.  But waiting isn’t a great option either. And it’s costing the company market share.  
Airbus
      ’ A320neo family of jets is outselling the MAX family of jets. Airbus has taken in more than 10,000 orders for its newest A320 family. Boeing has accumulated less than 8,000 orders for MAX jets.  Airbus’ larger A321neo has taken in more than 6,000 orders. The MAX 10—the longest version of the 737 MAX—has accumulated about 1,200 orders. The MAX 10 isn’t certified for commercial flight yet.  The prior generation of single-aisle numbers looks different. Airbus sold about 8,000 of its older model A320 family jets. Boeing sold about 8,500 prior-generation 737 jets that overlap with Airbus products. Before the A320neo and the MAX, Boeing and Airbus split the single-aisle market.  Eventually, Boeing needs a new plane to staunch market share losses. Calhoun’s number is a little scary. It might not be that bad. The last all-new plane Boeing developed was the 787 Dreamliner. The original cost of that program was supposed to be in the range of $5 billion. It ended up costing closer to $15 billion. With inflation, that number might be $25 billion today.  BofA Securities analyst Ron Epstein estimates a new single-aisle jet program would cost the company about $30 billion. That’s a “reasonable estimate for the new program, assuming no major challenges,” wrote the analyst in a Monday report.  That isn’t Calhoun’s $50 billion but not $15 billion or $25 billion either.  Calhoun’s $50 billion and Epstein’s $30 billion include all the development costs that go into a plane program including R&D, capital spending, and delays which are inevitable for almost every new plane program.  Calhoun is probably building in a buffer to temper expectations. Boeing didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment about his estimate.  The other thing a new plane program needs is time. Typically six to 10 years. Boeing better get started. The sooner the better.   Boeing stock closed down 1.8% Monday at $189.50 while the 
        S&P 500
       and 
        Dow Jones Industrial Average
       finished down 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively.  Through Monday trading, Boeing stock was down about 27% year to date. Most of that drop happened after the Jan. 5 737 MAX 9 incident.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Why value stocks with low P/E ratios deliver long-term. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
This Is Why You Don\u2019t Wait. Next Bo.short_description: This Is Why You Don’t Wait. Next Boeing Plane Could Cost $50 Billion.

United Airlines asks pilots to take time.title: United Airlines asks pilots to take time off in May due to shortage of new Boeing planes
United Airlines asks pilots to take time.text:
United Airlines is asking its pilots to take time off in May because of delays in receiving new planes that the airline ordered from Boeing, which is struggling with production due to manufacturing problems. A United 
        UAL,
        -1.50%
       spokesperson said Monday that the offer is voluntary. “Due to the recent delays in Boeing deliveries, our forecasted (flight hours) have been reduced and we are offering our pilots voluntary programs for the month of May to reduce excess staffing,” spokesperson Leslie Scott said. The Air Line Pilots Association said in a brief statement that United is offering short-term leaves and unpaid time off, but they are not mandatory. Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.33%
       declined to comment. United doesn’t expect to get all the Boeing jetliners it ordered and was due to receive this year or next year. A month ago, United said it was contractually due 191 planes this year and 127 next year, but expects to receive only 88 this year and 64 in 2025. Almost all of the shortfall consists of Boeing 737 Max planes, including a new, larger model. United had planned to begin flying 80 Max 10 jets this year. The Federal Aviation Administration has not yet certified the Max 10, however, and FAA approval is likely to be further delayed by increased scrutiny of Boeing since a panel blew out of an Alaska Airlines 
ALK,
        -1.32%
       Max 9 in January. United is considering options to replace orders for the Max 10. Since the Alaska Airlines accident, federal regulators have been investigating production-quality issues at Boeing, and the FAA has barred Boeing from increasing production of 737 Max jets. United previously said that it expects to lose money in the first quarter because its Max 9s were grounded for inspections for three weeks after the blowout on the Alaska plane. The Chicago-based airline is scheduled to release financial results April 16. United CEO Scott Kirby is one of several airline executives who have called out problems at Boeing and sought a meeting with Boeing directors. Boeing announced last week that CEO David Calhoun will step down at the end of the year as part of a leadership shakeup at the company. The head of Boeing’s commercial-airplanes unit has already been replaced, and the chairman of the board will not stand for re-election in May. Shares of Boeing Co. fell 1.6%, while United Airlines Holdings was down fractionally in afternoon trading Monday. The Google parent posts earnings ahead of expectations, helped in part by AI-driven demand for cloud computing. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
