        +2.34%,
       Arm Holdings 
        ARM,
        +3.84%,
       Advanced Micro Devices 
        AMD,
        +2.28%
       and the Global X Artificial Intelligence & Technology ETF 
        AIQ.
 Also don’t shed those weight-loss linked stocks such as Eli Lilly 
        LLY,
        +1.28%
       and Novo Nordisk 
        NVO,
        +0.85%
       or financials via Industrial Select Sector SPDR ETF 
        XLI
       and industrials via Financial Select Sector SPDR 
        XLF.
       He also is sticking with bitcoin and its proxies — Marathon Digital 
        MARA,
        +1.37%,
       PayPal 
        PYPL,
        +3.34%,
       Coinbase 
        COIN,
        +4.57%
       and MicroStrategy 
        MSTR,
        +2.59%.
 Stocks 
        SPX
COMP
       are struggling for traction, with bond yields 
        BX:TMUBMUSD10Y
BX:TMUBMUSD02Y
       also largely unchanged pre-Fed. Continued dollar 
        DXY
       strength has pushed the yen 
        USDJPY,
        +1.40%
close to multi-decade lows. Mr. Yen says intervention could happen soon. Oil 
        CL.1,
        +0.07%
       is down over 1%. Read: Foreign holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds declined in January from record highs Bitcoin 
        BTCUSD,
        -1.29%
       has pared losses and is back up above $63,900, but some see sub-$60,000 possible amid ETFs outflows. The Fed is expected to leave key interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of its two-day meeting in a decision due at 2 p.m. All eyes on the “dot plot” for rate forecasts and a news conference with Chairman Powell at 2:30 p.m. Follow MarketWatch’s Live Coverage PDD shares 
        PDD,
        +2.73%
       are flying after the parent of fast-fashion platform Temu reported forecast-beating results.  Chipotle stock 
        CMG,
        +2.44%
       is up 6% after the burrito chain said its board approved a 50-for-1 stock split. General Mills shares are headed for a 7-month high on a confirmed outlook and upbeat results. BioNTech 
        BNTX,
        +0.77%
       stock is dropping on earnings disappointment from the vaccine maker. Intel 
        INTC,
        -9.16%
will get up to $8.5 billion in federal funding via the Chips Act, and the chip company’s stock is up 3%. Elsewhere, the Biden administration reportedly may blacklist several Chinese chip firms linked to Huawei. Chip connectivity product maker Astera Labs will make its Nasdaq debut under symbol ALAB , after pricing its IPO  above target range. Boeing CFO says cash flow to be hit by p.title: Boeing CFO says cash flow to be hit by production delays
Boeing CFO says cash flow to be hit by p.text:
Boeing Co.’s chief financial officer on Wednesday said cash flow will be worse than the company had expected even back in January as the troubled plane maker focuses on quality after a spate of incidents. CFO Brian West told a Bank of America conference that lower deliveries, a worse mix and working capital pressure are all contributing to a hit of between $4 billion and $4.5 billion for the current quarter. Some of that, he added, will not be made up by the end of the year. Analysts polled by FactSet had forecast a $1 billion decline in cash flow from operations. Boeing shares 
        BA,
        +0.32%
       slipped in premarket trade, but reversed course to rise more than 2% later Wednesday. The stock has dived by 29% this year, contrasting with an advance of around 9% for the S&P 500 index 
        SPX
       in the same period. “For years we prioritized the movement of airplanes in the factory over getting it done right and that has got to change,” said West. Citi analyst Jason Gursky, commenting on West’s guidance, said the “long-term thesis [is] intact but near-term catalysts appear scarce.” Vertical Research Partners analyst Robert Stallard said that the guidance cut was “overdue,” and that it might still be “overly optimistic.”  Boeing “has no guarantee on what the FAA’s conclusion will be on the 737, and it is currently producing way below the official rate of 38/month. Withpotential Spirit integration risk on top and some of its Defense programs still struggling we think Boeing would be better off ditching the [$10 billion] FCF target until it has made more progress sorting out its myriad of problems,” Stallard said in a note. Boeing has previously said it was lowering the production rate on the 737 to below 38 per month. West, as he previously has stated, said it will be up to the Federal Aviation Administration to determine when the company can begin increasing production. Boeing has been under intense pressure since a fuselage panel flew off an Alaska Airlines 737 Max jet in January. More recently, Boeing told airlines to check 787 cockpit seats after a sudden plunge led to injuries. West talked about getting “traveled work” down and quality up as he reiterated the company may acquire contractor Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc. 
        SPR,
        +2.33%.
       “It’s really about focus, running that business as a factory rather than a business,” West said. Any deal would be financed by cash and debt and not by equity, he added. He said Boeing will only accept a fully conforming fuselage from Spirit at its Washington state factory. West added that achieving an investment-grade rating is still a priority but it will be on a timeline further out than 2025 to 2026. West did note that both the 787 and 737 are sold firm through 2028. “Commercial demand continues to be robust,” said West. Claudia Assis in San Francisco contributed. Pound falls as U.K. inflation at fresh 2.title: Pound falls as U.K. inflation at fresh 2-year low bolsters bets the Bank of England will adopt dovish tone on Thursday
Pound falls as U.K. inflation at fresh 2.text:
The pound and U.K. government bond yields fell Wednesday after a report showed inflation at its lowest in more than two years, raising hopes that the Bank of England can soon start trimming borrowing costs. Britain’s central bank is widely expected to leave its main interest rate at 5.25% on Thursday. However, news that consumer prices grew in the year to February by 3.4%, down from 4% in January, and the weakest reading since September 2021, saw traders bolster bets of a 25 basis point rate cut in June.  “A much more manageable 3.4%, cooler than had been expected, has already impacted market expectation of how many rate cuts the Bank of England might be able to push through by the end of the year,” said Danni Hewson, head of financial analysis at AJ Bell. “Money markets are once again pricing in four or even the off chance of five cuts [of 25 basis points apiece] by the end of the year, where yesterday just three seemed possible,” Hewson added. Marc Cogliatti, head of capital markets, EMEA at Validus Risk Management, noted that the headline inflation rate “was also below the Bank of England’s own forecasts implying there may be a little more scope for the Monetary Policy Committee to ease than previously thought.” “This message was reinforced by a dip in the core reading which fell from 5.1% in January to 4.6% in February,” Cogliatti added. Yields on the monetary policy-sensitive 2-year gilt 
        BX:TMBMKGB-02Y
       fell 5.2 basis points to 4.234%, close to a two-month low, while the pound 
        GBPUSD,
        -0.18%
       dipped 0.2% to trade below $1.27. The U.K. currency hit an eight-month peak near $1.29 less than two weeks ago as investors built bets that the British economy was faring better than many observers thought it would and that inflation was proving stubbornly sticky. However, since then slower wage growth data has shown easing pressures in the jobs market, which when combined with the latest consumer prices report means the market is now poised for a dovish BOE on Thursday, according to Kathleen Brooks, analyst at XTB. “With progress made on wage increases and inflation, there is a chance no one will vote for a hike at this meeting. This could be seen as a step closer to the BOE cutting interest rates,” said Brooks. The FTSE 100 equity index 
        UK:UKX
       was down 0.2% but the more domestically focused and rate-sensitive FTSE 250 index 
        UK:MCX
       rose 0.1%.   Alphabet shares surge after Google’s parent posts better-than-expected earnings and announces its first cash dividend, Microsoft posts 31% quarterly growth in Azure cloud-computing revenue, and Exxon Mobil’s earnings miss estimates.  Jamie Chisholm is a markets reporter based in London. Jamie Chisholm is a markets reporter based in London. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.

Bitcoin\u2019s Slump Is the First Test f.title: Bitcoin’s Slump Is the First Test for ETF Enthusiasm, What’s Next for Cryptos. And 5 Other Things to Know Before Markets Open.
Bitcoin\u2019s Slump Is the First Test f.text:
Bitcoin is up to its old tricks again. Despite taking a large step toward mainstream acceptance, and a huge leap to fresh all-time highs, the cryptocurrency reminded investors Tuesday that a wild swing lower is never that far away. The price of Bitcoin tumbled below $63,000 after hitting a record high close to $74,000 last week. While it’s always difficult to assign a value to crypto assets, the bull case for Bitcoin can still be made. The approval of spot exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in January has increased interest among institutional and retail investors. It has also accelerated the move toward mainstream acceptance and ETFs last week posted record inflows. The so-called halving event, which cuts the rate at which new tokens are issued, is expected next month and historically helps push prices higher. Appetite for riskier assets in general, such as high-growth technology stocks, also aids digital assets—the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite is sitting just below its record high. But the price correction provides a major test for Bitcoin and its recent resurgence. It’s the asset’s biggest fall in value since spot ETFs began trading.  If surging inflows helped Bitcoin reach new highs, then a mass exodus may well have the opposite effect. On the flip side, if those who have bought into Bitcoin ETFs prove to be unfazed by the price action it could shore up the asset’s recent strength. The answer to that question won’t be clear for a while but Tuesday did mark record daily net outflows of $326.2 million from U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs, according to data from BitMEX Research. However, Grayscale’s Bitcoin Trust accounted for $444 million in outflows but it does highlight a lack of buying among other funds. Bitcoin is at a crossroads—it’s time for the investors who have joined the crypto party this year to show whether they are in it for the long haul or just to take profits. —Callum Keown 
Microsoft
       has hired artificial intelligence entrepreneur Mustafa Suleyman and Karén Simonyan from Inflection AI, a start-up, to run its new Microsoft AI arm, which will be responsible for the Copilot chatbot and its other generative AI software. The move raises questions about Microsoft’s future plans for OpenAI. What’s Next: Inflection’s new CEO is Sean White, a board member and previously chief R&D officer at Mozilla. Inflection said it would continue to test and fine-tune its custom generative AI models for commercial customers, and will host its Inflection-2.5 software on Microsoft Azure. —Janet H. Cho and Eric J. Savitz Lawmakers are racing to finalize a bill to fund the rest of the federal government through September after reaching an agreement on spending for the Department of Homeland Security. President Joe Biden and congressional leaders announced the deal, and Biden urged its swift passage to avoid a partial shutdown. What’s Next: There’s a chance the voting won’t be complete by Friday’s deadline, which means a partial government shutdown while the process is completed, or a last-minute extension. Both the House and Senate are scheduled to recess for two weeks starting Saturday. —Liz Moyer In a year that had fewer mergers and initial public offerings, greater stock market volatility, regional bank failures, and less generous compensation policies, the size of the average Wall Street bonus dropped to the lowest level since 2019, according to New York State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli. What’s Next: Since September 2023, Wall Street securities employees are more likely than other New York City employees to be working in the office rather than from home, spending money in the city, and riding the subway, DiNapoli’s office said. —Janet H. Cho More new-home construction and rising builder confidence mean home buyers could see more options this spring selling season and beyond. If mortgage rates keep falling, National Association of Home Builders Chairman Carl Harris expects more consumers to jump off the sidelines and into the marketplace. What’s Next: Capital Economics economist Thomas Ryan expects housing construction to take different paths over the next two years. Single family construction is expected to benefit from a dearth of previously owned homes for sale, while multifamily construction is expected to be weaker. —Shaina Mishkin and Janet H. Cho JetBlue Airways is cutting several weaker-performing routes to prioritize its stronger routes when the number of aircraft available is limited. The airline’s new CEO Joanna Geraghty vowed to take “aggressive action” to return it to profitability when she took over last month. She has already announced plans to defer $2.5 billion in aircraft spending and other cost-cutting measures. What’s Next: The airline is planning for a future without 
        Spirit Airlines
       after its proposed merger with the ultra-low-cost carrier was blocked by a federal judge, and then terminated by the companies earlier this month. —Callum Keown Dear Quentin, My friend invested $50,000 in her brother’s home-renovation and flipping business in 2007. He had been very successful in this business, but soon thereafter they got caught up in the 2008 crash, and lost absolutely everything, including her $50,000 investment.  At the time, she was very close to dying of cancer, and had three teenage children, so she begged her brother to pay her kids $50,000 whenever he recovered financially. So he promised he would do that, and she informed her kids that he would do this.  He is 73 now, has just retired from his job so there is no supplemental income, and his Social Security income is only $2,000 a month, which he started taking when he was 62. There is no way he can repay that remaining balance.  There was no written documentation for the original investment nor for the promise to pay it back. His sister’s kids want his house to be sold to pay off the debt upon his death. He wants to leave his house—worth about $200,000 with a $28,000 mortgage—to his own adult children.  Will his estate have to sell the house out from under his two kids? He has signed a transfer-on-death deed to his kids, but I told him that I don’t think that protects the house from being sold to pay off any debts at his death. He lives in Texas, and has no credit-card debt.  Any advice you can provide would be helpful. —On His Tail for 16 Years Read the Moneyist’s response here. —Quentin Fottrell —Newsletter edited by Liz Moyer, Patrick O’Donnell, Rupert Steiner The Google parent posts earnings ahead of expectations, helped in part by AI-driven demand for cloud computing. U.K. inflation falls by more than expect.title: U.K. inflation falls by more than expected in February, triggering talk of lower interest rates
U.K. inflation falls by more than expect.text:
LONDON (AP) — Price rises in the U.K. eased by more than anticipated in February, official figures showed Wednesday, raising expectations that the Bank of England may start cutting interest rates in the next few months. The Office for National Statistics said inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, fell to 3.4%, its lowest level since September 2021, from 4% in January. The agency said easing food price inflation was largely behind the fall. The decrease was bigger than anticipated. Analysts had expected a decline to 3.6%. The yield on the 2-year gilt 
        BX:TMBMKGB-02Y
       fell 10 basis points to 4.19%. The pound 
        GBPUSD,
        -0.18%
       fell to $1.2696 from $1.2723 on Tuesday. Inflation is still running higher than the Bank of England’s target of 2% but the direction of the move is clear. Inflation hit a high above 11% at the end of 2022 in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which led to sharp increases in energy costs. The bigger-than-anticipated decline comes a day before the nine rate-setters at the bank announce their latest interest rate decision. The view in financial markets is that they will keep the main interest rate at a 16-year high of 5.25%. “So far, the BoE has been reluctant to give very strong guidance about the precise timing of the first cut. But after two years of economic stagnation following the massive gas supply shock in early 2022, policymakers will likely be hoping to take their foot off the monetary policy brake soon to support an already building recovery,” said Kallum Pickering, senior economist at Berenberg. The meeting minutes will be assessed to see how much thought policymakers are giving to cutting interest rates, which should feed through to lower mortgage rates. “This notable decline is further evidence that the U.K. is fast approaching the finish line in its battle against surging inflation,” said Suren Thiru, economics director at the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. The Bank of England, like the Fed and other central banks around the world, raised interest rates aggressively in late 2021 from near zero to counter price rises first stoked by supply chain issues during the coronavirus pandemic and then Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which pushed up food and energy costs. Higher interest rates — which cool the economy by making it more expensive to borrow, thereby bearing down on spending — have contributed to bringing down inflation worldwide. Britain’s governing Conservative Party hopes that lower inflation and falling interest rates may trigger a feelgood factor ahead of a general election, which has to take place by January 2025. Opinion polls show the main opposition Labour Party way ahead and headed for a big victory over the Conservatives, who have been in power since 2010. — MarketWatch contributed to this report. Consumer sentiment deteriorated near the end of April, according to the latest reading from the University of Michigan. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
U.K. inflation falls by more than expect.short_description: U.K. inflation falls by more than expected in February, triggering talk of lower interest rates

Investors Don\u2019t Need to Sweat the L.title: Investors Don’t Need to Sweat the Latest Boeing 737 Safety Incident. The Data Show Why.
Investors Don\u2019t Need to Sweat the L.text:
A Friday incident involving a 
        Boeing
       jet, in which the plane lost a panel midflight, has resulted in more negative headlines for the aircraft manufacturer—and generated even more questions about airplane safety. Now Boeing investors, whether they like it or not, have to prepare themselves for Monday’s trading session with as much detail—and context—as possible.  On Friday, a 
        United Airlines
       flight was found to be missing an external panel when it landed in Oregon. The plane involved was a 25-year-old 737 NG, or Next Generation, model. Boeing’s 737 MAX jets are newer models—and have essentially replaced the NG jets in the company’s product lineup.  No emergency was declared and the plane is being inspected and repaired, according to United.  Still, every incident involving a Boeing plane is investor-level news after Jan. 5, when a 737 MAX 9’s emergency door plug blew out during an 
        Alaska Air
       flight. Barron’s looked at aviation incidents recorded in the National Transportation Safety Board, or NTSB, database which involved Boeing and 
        Airbus
       jets over the past 12 months. There were 53 incidents involving U.S.-registered jets operated by at least a dozen airlines during this time period, including almost a dozen plane models.  Incidents can be many things. They can happen on the tarmac while a plane is taxiing, ascending, flying midair, or landing. They can also happen anywhere in the world; the NTSB database is global.  Barron’s found 37 incidents involving Boeing jets and 16 involving Airbus jets. It makes sense for Boeing to have more incidents: Major U.S. airlines have some 3,400 Boeing jets in their fleets, double the roughly 1,700 Airbus planes.    The 53 incidents work out to just over four incidents a month for a U.S.-registered commercial airline—which means about 0.1% of the U.S. fleet is affected.    The data show that older planes have more issues than younger planes. Over the past 12 months, the incident rate for Boeing planes between 20 and 30 years old is about two a month. The incident rate for planes up to 10 years old is about one a month.  The incident rate for newer Airbus jets looks the same—about one a month. That means newer Boeing jets slightly outperform Airbus jets, given the latter’s smaller fleet. Still, the numbers are small.  Airbus jets between 20 and 30 years old have six incidents recorded in the NTSB database over the past 12 months. That’s impressive—but small numbers make it difficult to declare something definitive. The big takeaways: Overall incident rates are low, incidents appear to happen to older planes at a higher rate than newer jets, and numbers for Boeing and Airbus look similar—on the surface.   The data also show that 47—or 89%—of the incidents involved planes more than three years old. Airlines have been operating almost all of the jets for years. The “average plane” in the data covering the past 12 months was delivered in 2004, making it roughly 20 years old.   Boeing and Airbus didn’t respond to Barron’s requests for comment on our analysis. The Federal Aviation Administration said in an emailed statement: ”FAA regulations require aircraft to undergo regular inspections, maintenance, and parts overhauls and replacement as specified in the aircraft maintenance manual and any applicable Airworthiness Directives. The FAA also has specific inspection requirements for older aircraft.”  Investors must consider safety data because Boeing has legitimate safety, quality, and production issues. Boeing stock was north of $440 a share before the second tragic 737 MAX crash in 2019.  This year, Boeing stock was at $249 a share before the door plug failure in January. Boeing shares closed at $182.53 on Friday, off 30% in 2024, making it the second worst-performing stock in the 
        S&P 500
       this year. (
        Tesla
       stock is the worst.)  MAX issues over the past few years make all Boeing-related aviation incidents news—for now. Investors simply must learn how to contextualize each incident and decide whether they represent production, design, maintenance issues—or human error.  The issue involving the United flight on Friday appears to fall in the maintenance category. The FAA and NTSB should eventually weigh in on the root causes of the problem. Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Investors Don\u2019t Need to Sweat the L.short_description: Investors Don’t Need to Sweat the Latest Boeing 737 Safety Incident. The Data Show Why.

Boeing Might Sell Part of Its Defense Bu.title: Boeing Might Sell Part of Its Defense Business. Here’s What That Could Mean.
Boeing Might Sell Part of Its Defense Bu.text:
Boeing
       might sell part of its defense business, Bloomberg reported Tuesday.  Wall Street, and investors, will be interested in any sale. It’s too early to tell exactly what might be sold, so for now, investors should prepare and watch for what’s next.   Boeing declined to comment on the Bloomberg report.  Boeing’s defense business, which it calls Boeing Defense, Space & Security, generated about $25 billion in 2023 sales and an operating loss of about $1.8 billion. It was the second consecutive annual loss for the unit. Fixed-price contracts and higher-than-expected inflation have been an issue for many defense contractors in recent years.  In the five years before the pandemic, the business generated an average operating profit of about $2.3 billion a year, corresponding to a profit margin of about 9%.  Wall Street expects sales to hit about $25.6 billion in 2024, up about 3%. Operating profit is projected to be positive at about $546 million.  Boeing isn’t all that active in M&A. The most significant sale in the recent past was the 2005 sale of the business that is now 
        Spirit AeroSystems
       to Canadian private-equity player Onex. Boeing is now considering buying Spirit Aero to gain more control of its manufacturing process.  Boeing bought some parts distribution in 2018 for about $4.2 billion.  Any sale that raises billions can help pay down debt. Boeing ended 2023 with about $54 billion in total debt, according to Bloomberg. That’s up from about $14 billion before two Boeing 737 MAX crashes and the pandemic.  Boeing didn’t generate positive free cash flow in 2019, 2020, or 2021. But it reported $2.3 billion and $4.4 billion in free cash flow in 2022 and 2023, respectively, according to FactSet. Wall Street expects $5 billion in free cash flow for 2024.  Boeing stock was up 0.7% in midday trading with the 
        S&P 500
       up 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite up about 0.4%. Through midday trading, Boeing stock was off about 31% year to date.  Those declines are mainly related to problems with the 737 MAX program. An emergency-door plug blew out of a 737 MAX 9 jet operated by 
        Alaska Air
       on Jan. 5, leading to questions about Boeing’s quality and manufacturing process as well as more oversight from the Federal Aviation Administration.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com   Buying stocks after the “final rate hike” in a cycle demands perfect timing. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Boeing Might Sell Part of Its Defense Bu.short_description: Boeing Might Sell Part of Its Defense Business. Here’s What That Could Mean.

Buy Airbus Stock, Analyst Says. Boeing I.title: Buy Airbus Stock, Analyst Says. Boeing Is One Reason Why.
Buy Airbus Stock, Analyst Says. Boeing I.text:
Airbus
       stock caught an upgrade to Buy. 
        Boeing’s
recent struggles are a factor in the improved outlook.  On Tuesday, RBC analyst Ken Herbert upgraded shares of Airbus to Buy from Hold. His target for the price went to €192 ($208) from €145 ($157).  Airbus stock was up 2% in overseas trading at €166.50 a share, leaving shares up about 19% so far this year and up about 43% over the past 12 months.  “We believe the recent positive shift in sentiment has room to run as recent narrowbody share gains could expand further and investor confidence in the mid-decade targets improves,” wrote Herbert.  Narrow-body planes are single-aisle jets such as the A320 and 737 MAX family of aircraft. The positive sentiment shift is the one from Boeing to Airbus as Boeing struggles through more problems with its MAX jets. The Jan. 5 midair blowout of an emergency-door plug on a MAX jet led the Federal Aviation Administration to cap Boeing’s MAX production at 38 a month, but Airbus can make closer to 50 A320 jets a month. Airbus plans to take production to about 75 a month over the coming couple of years. Boeing wanted to get to 50 MAX jets a month, but additional FAA oversight will delay the increase in production.  Market share shifts slowly between Boeing and Airbus, and a tilt toward Airbus now under way isn’t likely to stop for the foreseeable future, Herbert believes. That is what makes him confident that Airbus can reach its mid-decade targets. “Incumbency is a powerful competitive advantage in aerospace markets,” wrote Herbert. “We believe Airbus will capture about 55% of the total 2024 to 2026 narrowbody deliveries.”  He projects Airbus’s 2025 free cash flow will reach about €6.2 billion, similar to Wall Street estimates, and up from a projected €4.3 billion for 2024.  Herbert’s stock-price target of €192 works out to about 24 times his estimate for 2025 free cash flow per share. His target price for Boeing stock is $260, about 20 times his estimate of per-share free cash flow for 2025.  Herbert rates Boeing stock Buy as well, which is the prevailing stance on Wall Street: 69% of analysts covering Boeing rate the shares at Buy. The average Buy-rating ratio for stocks in the 
        S&P 500
       is about 55%. The average analyst price target for Boeing shares is about $261, while the stock was at $180.09 early on Tuesday.  Overall, 83% of analysts covering Airbus stock rate shares Buy. The average analyst price target is about €169 ($184) a share.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. Buy Airbus Stock, Analyst Says. Boeing I.short_description: Buy Airbus Stock, Analyst Says. Boeing Is One Reason Why.

United Airlines CEO looks to reassure cu.title: United Airlines CEO looks to reassure customers that airline is safe after recent incidents
United Airlines CEO looks to reassure cu.text:
The CEO of United Airlines says that a slew of recent incidents — ranging from a piece of aluminum skin falling off a plane to another jet losing a wheel on takeoff — will cause the airline to review its safety training for employees. CEO Scott Kirby said the airline 
        UAL,
        -1.52%
       was already planning an extra day of training for pilots starting in May and changes in training curriculum for newly hired mechanics. In a memo to customers on Monday, Kirby tried to reassure travelers that safety is the airline’s top priority. “Unfortunately, in the past few weeks, our airline has experienced a number of incidents that are reminders of the importance of safety,” he said. “While they are all unrelated, I want you to know that these incidents have our attention and have sharpened our focus.” Kirby said the airline is reviewing each recent incident and will use what it learns to “inform” safety training and procedures. He did not give any details beyond measures that he said were already being planned, such as the extra day of training for pilots. Some of the recent incidents — such as cracks in multi-layer windshields — don’t normally attract much attention, but have gained news coverage and clicks on social media because of the sheer number of events affecting one airline in a short period of time. To a degree, United may be a victim of heightened concern about air safety since January, when a panel blew off an Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.56%
       Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.37%
       737 Max at 16,000 feet above Oregon. Investigators say bolts securing the panel were missing. “I don’t see a major safety issue at United,” said John Cox, former airline pilot and now a safety consultant. “The media is enhancing the events with extra scrutiny. Anything right now that happens to a United airplane makes the news.” Cox said the incidents “are unfortunate, and they are getting a lot of attention, but I don’t see that they are showing an erosion in the safety of the commercial-aviation system.” In the most recent incident at United, on Friday, a chunk of the outer aluminum skin fell off the belly of a Boeing 737-800 that was built in 1998. Also last week, a United flight from Dallas to San Francisco suffered a hydraulic leak, and another flight bound for San Francisco returned to Australia two hours after takeoff because of an undescribed “maintenance issue.” Earlier this month, a United flight returned to Houston after an engine caught fire, and a tire fell off a United Boeing 777 during takeoff in San Francisco. United planes have even had mishaps while on the ground. Last month, pilots on one plane reported that rudder pedals used to steer on the runway briefly failed after touchdown in Newark, N.J. This month, a jet landing in Houston rolled off an airport taxiway and got stuck in grass. Workers had to haul out moveable stairs to help passengers exit the plane. There were no injuries in any of the incidents, several of which are under investigation by federal officials. Dividends are a sign of maturing companies, but may also be a diversion for investors amid hefty capital spending Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
United Airlines CEO looks to reassure cu.short_description: United Airlines CEO looks to reassure customers that airline is safe after recent incidents

Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed, BOJ Decis.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed, BOJ Decisions the Highlight of a Central-Bank Meeting Spree
Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed, BOJ Decis.text:
Below are the most important global events likely to affect FX and bond markets in the coming week starting Monday, March 18. A number of central-bank meetings in both Europe and Asia will be the focus of a busy week, most notably decisions by the U.S. Federal Reserve as investors hunt for clues as to the timing of a first rate cut, and by the Bank of Japan, which could opt to exit negative interest rates. Other central-bank decisions are due in China, Australia and the U.K., as well as Indonesia, Taiwan, Switzerland and Norway. Chinese economic data will be watched closely for signs of recovery at the start of the year. U.S. The Federal Reserve announces a policy decision on Wednesday, where interest rates are expected to be left on hold and markets will scrutinize any comments that provide hints on when the central bank could start lowering rates. Markets are fully pricing in a rate cut in July, with a sizeable chance of an earlier move in June, Refinitiv data show. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in testimony recently that interest rates had peaked and were likely to be cut this year. U.S. economic data continue to suggest that the economy is holding up well, while recent figures showed inflation unexpectedly rose in February, which will likely concern some policymakers. U.S. economic data releases start with housing on Tuesday, followed by weekly jobless claims and existing home sales on Thursday. JAPAN The BOJ's decision on Tuesday will be closely watched by global investors as bets have been growing recently about the central bank's imminent exit from negative interest rates and its yield-curve control policy. Analysts and investors expect the BOJ to raise its key short-term interest rate from minus 0.1% either in March or in April. Policymakers have grown more confident that a positive cycle of higher wages and higher prices is finally starting to kick in after decades of deflation, with many companies saying they will raise wages significantly this year. However, views are split on whether the BOJ should follow up by raising interest rates into positive territory, and if so, how quickly. According to people familiar with the BOJ's thinking, the bank is likely to move slowly in raising rates above zero if it does decide to end negative rates, given Japan's fragile momentum on prices. "If the bank raises short-term rates too rapidly, it could damage the economy," said one of the people familiar with the BOJ's thinking. "Any policy inaction or indication of little urgency from the BOJ could suggest that markets have gotten ahead of themselves, which may tame hawkish rate bets and potentially weigh on the yen," said Yeap Jun Rong, market analyst at IG. Any near-term pullback "could still be a temporary move," however. CHINA After the highly-anticipated "Two Sessions" gathering of policymakers failed to give markets much to cheer about, fresh data for January-February will indicate whether the world's second-largest economy is picking up. Sentiment is low after February home-price data showed continued declines. That adds to views that the stimulus undertaken so far isn't doing much to boost the property sector, fanning concerns that the sector downturn will continue dragging on China's economy for some time. Figures for retail sales, fixed asset investment and industrial output are set to be released on Monday. On Wednesday, focus will be on the loan prime rate (LPR) announcement by the People's Bank of China amid expectations of more monetary-policy support in the pipeline but a lack of clarity on what shape this will take. The PBOC held its one-year medium-term lending facility unchanged on Friday, signaling that the LPR will also stay steady. Commercial banks in China are asked to price their LPR with medium-term lending facility rates. Last month, the one-year LPR, which is tied to many personal and corporate loans, was left unchanged the previous month while the five-year LPR, which is linked to mortgages, was lowered. "The PBOC remains on a dovish tilt, but depreciation pressure on the renminbi limits room for monetary easing in China before global central banks start to cut rates," said Lynn Song, ING's chief economist for Greater China. HSBC economists Jing Liu and Erin Xin see more likelihood that the central bank will use liquidity tools like another cut to lenders' reserves requirement and structural tools like targeted relending rather than interest-rate cuts in the near term. EUROZONE Data in the eurozone is relatively sparse in the coming week but will still be watched given prospects of the European Central Bank cutting interest rates in the coming months and as concerns remain about the fragility of the eurozone economy even as it slowly recovers. Monday's final estimate of eurozone inflation for February will be important, while Thursday's provisional purchasing managers' surveys for March will be key for indicating how well the economy is recovering. Other surveys include the latest German ZEW survey on Tuesday, eurozone consumer confidence on Wednesday and the German Ifo sentiment indicator on Friday. Government bond supply in the eurozone will be spread across sovereigns, with smaller countries joining the four big issuers. Slovakia and Belgium will sell bonds on Monday; Finland on Tuesday; Germany on Wednesday; Spain, France and Ireland on Thursday and Italy on Friday. Eurozone benchmark issuer Germany will tap bonds at the long-end, auctioning 2044- and 2052-dated Bunds. In Scandinavia Denmark and Sweden will conduct auctions on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. U.K. The Bank of England is expected to keep rates unchanged at 5.25% when it announces its policy decision on Thursday. A relatively robust U.K. economy means most investors expect the BOE to start cutting rates later than the U.S. Fed and the ECB, but still the tone of the statement will be scrutinized for clues. Ahead of the meeting, BOE policymakers could be influenced by Wednesday's U.K. inflation data for February, which will be watched closely. Producer prices data are also due on Wednesday and the U.K.'s purchasing managers' surveys for March are released on Thursday. "Our baseline is that [BOE] policy guidance will be unchanged, although a particularly weak inflation print...may give members enough conviction to soften language further," Barclays analysts said in a note. On Tuesday, the U.K. Debt Management Office will auction 2053-dated government bonds, or gilts. AUSTRALIA The Reserve Bank of Australia's policy decision on Tuesday will be the key focus of Australian bond traders next week. RBA Governor Michele Bullock is widely expected to keep the official cash rate unchanged at 4.35%. While painting a balanced view of the economic outlook, she is likely to maintain the threat of more interest-rate increases. Most economists expect that the RBA is in no rush to adjust its policy position, and will hold the line until either there is further evidence that inflation has fallen, or unemployment spikes upward. The week will end with the RBA releasing its latest report card on financial stability. CANADA Canadian inflation data for February will be watched on Tuesday for clues on whether prices are coming down sufficiently to allow the Bank of Canada to cut interest rates in the coming months. NORWAY Norges Bank, Norway's central bank, is expected to leave its key interest rate on hold at 4.5% on Thursday, with focus on the accompanying statement. Norway's solid economy means a rate cut isn't expected until later in the year. SWITZERLAND The Swiss National Bank announces a rate decision on Thursday. Investors will be watching to see whether the SNB leaves its policy rate on hold at 1.75% and waits until June to cut, or whether it opts to cut rates this month given falling inflation and its concerns about the impact of a strong Swiss franc on Swiss exporters. LATIN AMERICA Central-bank decisions are due from Brazil on Wednesday and Mexico on Thursday. INDONESIA Bank Indonesia announces a decision on Wednesday after keeping rates on hold again at its last meeting in February. BI has said it plans to start easing this year if inflation stays contained, economic growth resilient and the rupiah stable. Many economists expect it will move cautiously, with a rate cut only coming toward the end of the year if at all. UOB's Global Economics & Market Research team thinks BI will stand pat in 2024, but notes several downside risks to the Southeast Asian country's economic growth and IDR stability. These include prolonged geopolitical tensions, weaker demand from China and Japan, and slower disinflation in the U.S., which could delay Fed rate cuts and, consequently, BI's easing cycle. IDR has narrowed losses as political uncertainties ebbed after mid-February elections, but concerns of a widening fiscal deficit due to new spending programs are likely to dent sentiment, at least in the near term, the UOB team said. "We are still of the view that IDR would join the regional FX recovery when the Fed cuts rates in June." It expects USD/IDR at 15,500 in 2Q and 15,200 in 3Q. TAIWAN On Thursday, it is the Taiwanese central bank's turn to decide on monetary-policy settings. The CBC stood pat at its last meeting in December, citing expectations of easing inflation, alongside concerns that cooling global economies could disrupt domestic growth. While inflation is expected to cool further in the second half of 2024, UOB's Global Economics & Market Research team sees no compelling reasons for the central bank to start cutting interest rates this year, especially as an economic growth rebound could spark price pressures. It expects CBC to stay on hold for the rest of 2024. CBC holding rates steady relative to the Fed would likely bode well for the Taiwan dollar, said the UOB team led by head of research Suan Teck Kin. An upturn in global electronics demand and the stabilization of China's economy would also aid a Taiwan dollar recovery. SINGAPORE On Monday, Enterprise Singapore will release Singapore's nonoil domestic exports for February. In January, nonoil domestic exports returned to growth in a surprising show of strength, signaling that the worst of the trade slump that has weighed on the country's economy may have passed. Nonoil domestic exports rose 16.8% in January from a year earlier, following December's 1.5% contraction. (All references to days for Asian events are in local times.) --Additional reporting by Megumi Fujikawa, James Glynn, Ronnie Harui, Emese Bartha, Miriam Mukuru and Dominic Chopping Write to Jessica Fleetham at jessica.fleethma@wsj.com and Fabiana Negrin Ochoa at fabiana.negrinochoa@wsj.com Tesla stock has risen for three consecutive days, after falling for seven straight.  Dow Jones Newswires is a market-moving financial and business news source,

                     the world to identify trading and investing opportunities, strengthen advisor-client
                     relationships and build investor experiences. Learn More. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed, BOJ Decis.short_description: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed, BOJ Decisions the Highlight of a Central-Bank Meeting Spree

Boeing tells airlines to check pilot sea.title: Boeing tells airlines to check pilot seats after accidental movement reportedly led to plane’s plunge
Boeing tells airlines to check pilot sea.text:
Boeing is telling airlines to inspect switches on pilots’ seats in its 787 Dreamliner jets after a published report said an accidental cockpit-seat movement likely caused the sudden plunge of a LATAM Airlines plane flying to New Zealand. Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.31%
       said Friday it recommended that airlines inspect the motorized cockpit seats the next time they perform maintenance on their 787s. The aircraft manufacturer pointed to instructions that include how to disable motors that move the seats. The company described its advisory as a “precautionary measure.” It did not link the memo to what happened this week on a LATAM Airlines 
LTM,
        +1.69%
LTMAY,
        -2.65%
       flight between Australia and New Zealand. The Federal Aviation Administration said, however, that the Boeing memo was issued “in response to the incident on LATAM Flight 800.” The FAA said it was convening a panel of experts to review Boeing’s message to airlines. LATAM Airlines, based in Chile, initially said there was “a technical event during the flight which caused a strong movement.” In an update Tuesday, the airline said the plane “experienced a strong shake during flight, the cause of which is currently under investigation.” Passengers reported that when the Dreamliner dropped without warning, people not wearing seatbelts were tossed from their seats and into the cabin’s ceiling and aisles. The plane later landed at Auckland Airport as scheduled. About 50 people were injured, according to emergency crews in Auckland. The 787 is a two-aisle plane that debuted in 2011 and is used mostly for long international flights. The version involved in the LATAM flight can carry up to about 300 passengers. United Airlines 
        UAL,
        -1.66%,
       with 71 Dreamliners, and American Airlines 
        AAL,
        -2.19%,
       with 59, are among the leading users of the plane. American said Boeing’s instructions would have no impact on its operations. United declined to comment. The Wall Street Journal reported late Thursday that a flight attendant serving a meal in the cockpit hit a switch on the back of a seat that pushed the pilot into controls on the 787, pushing down the nose of the plane. The newspaper cited anonymous U.S. industry officials who were briefed on preliminary findings from the investigation. The newspaper said Boeing recommended that airlines check to make sure the switches are securely covered — they are not supposed to be used during flights — and told them how to turn off power to the seat motor. Chile’s aviation regulator has sent investigators to New Zealand and, under international accords, will lead the investigation. It has not released any findings. The incident could ratchet up scrutiny of Boeing, which is already at a high level since a panel blew out of an Alaska Airlines 737 Max over Oregon in January. The FAA, the National Transportation Safety Board and the Justice Department are conducting separate investigations related to the blowout and Boeing’s manufacturing of Max jets. Google parent Alphabet Inc.’s stock soared 12% in after-hours trading Thursday following huge spikes in revenue and net income that trounced analysts’ predictions — as well as its first-ever cash dividend of 20 cents per share. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Boeing tells airlines to check pilot sea.short_description: Boeing tells airlines to check pilot seats after accidental movement reportedly led to plane’s plunge

Bitcoin Bulls Await the Halving. Here\u2.title: Bitcoin Bulls Await the Halving. Here’s a Guide.
Bitcoin Bulls Await the Halving. Here\u2.text:
Bitcoin
       neared $74,000 this past week, with crypto bulls expecting more gains despite a sharp Friday correction. One reason: a cut in Bitcoin new issuance known as a “halving.” A key Bitcoin feature is that tokens increase at a predictable rate. New tokens go into circulation every time Bitcoin “miners” win a computing race to validate a block of transactions. The reward for each block is now 6.25 Bitcoins, worth $437,500 at $70,000. That will be cut to 3.125 Bitcoins in April, when the next halving occurs. Halvings happen roughly every four years and will continue until Bitcoins in circulation hit 21 million tokens. So far, more than 19.6 million Bitcoins have been mined, leaving 1.4 million to be issued. Since Bitcoin has no underlying value—only a cost to produce—its price is subject to supply and demand. Halving tends to restrict supply. After the last halving in 2020, Bitcoin gained more than 80% in six months and over 500% a year later, notes crypto tax firm CoinLedger. Now, demand has been fueled by new spot Bitcoin ETFs. “The drop in the amount of mined Bitcoin a day means something has to give—and, in this case, that means price has to give,” says Zachary Townsend, CEO of crypto-focused insurance firm Meanwhile.  Miners are less bullish. After surging in 2023, 
        Marathon Digital
       and 
        Riot Platforms
       are both down 27% in the past month, with Bitcoin up more than 40%.  Bitcoin broke $73,000 only to fall back to about $69,000. Stocks struggled against sticky inflation data: The U.S. consumer price index for February came in at 0.4%, or 3.2% year over year, and producer prices were at 0.6%, over the forecast. Retail sales were soft, and tech stocks took a beating. On the week, the 
        Dow industrials
       lost 0.02%, the 
        S&P 500
       was off 0.13%, and the 
        Nasdaq Composite
       shed 0.7%. The House voted to force ByteDance to divest its popular TikTok app, or be banned in the U.S. The National Association of Realtors agreed to pay $418 million in damages and abandon 6% commissions, a deal that now goes before a federal judge. 
        Boeing’s
       737 Max failed 33 of 89 regulatory audits, and the Justice Department is looking into criminal charges in the Alaska Airlines blown-door episode. With Bitcoin up, 
        Coinbase Global
       said it was raising a billion dollars in convertible debt. 
        Dollar Tree
       is closing 1,000 Family Dollar stores.  Natural-gas giant 
        EQT
       agreed to buy pipeline company 
        Equitrans Midstream
       for $5.5 billion, all in stock...Reddit began its initial-public-offering roadshow, looking to raise $748 million on a valuation of up to $6.4 billion...Telegram founder Pavel Durov told the Financial Times he was considering an IPO after achieving profitability in 2025. Telegram has 900 million members...
        Alcoa
       agreed to buy Australia’s Alumina for $2.2 billion...President Biden came out against 
        Nippon Steel’s
       buy of 
        U.S. Steel.
 Write to Robert Teitelman at bob.teitelman@dowjones.com A busy week for global central banks commences, with the 
        Bank of Japan
       announcing its monetary-policy decision. Traders are pricing in about a 50% chance that the central bank will raise its key short-term interest rate to zero from negative 0.1%, which would end the BOJ’s negative interest-rate policy that has been in effect since early 2016. The Reserve Bank of Australia also announces its decision on Tuesday, with the Bank of England and 
        Swiss National Bank
       following suit on Thursday. Only a handful of large-capitalization companies report results this week. Memory-chip maker 
        Micron Technology
       releases earnings on Wednesday, followed by 
        Accenture,
FedEx,
lululemon athletica,
       and 
        Nike
       on Thursday. The Federal Open Market Committee announces its monetary-policy decision and releases an updated Summary of Economic Projections. The FOMC is widely expected to keep the federal-funds rate unchanged at a multidecade high of 5.25% to 5.50%. In December, the SEP showed that the FOMC forecast three quarter-point interest-rate cuts in 2024. Wall Street began this year expecting roughly six quarter-point rate cuts but has since pared that back to about three. Despite this, the S&P 500 index has made 17 records highs this year. Email: editors@barrons.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Bitcoin Bulls Await the Halving. Here\u2.short_description: Bitcoin Bulls Await the Halving. Here’s a Guide.

United Airlines Is Looking For More Airb.title: United Airlines Is Looking For More Airbus Jets. It’s Another Blow for Boeing.
United Airlines Is Looking For More Airb.text:
Boeing
       investors got more potential bad news about the company’s troubled 737 MAX program this week: 
        United Airlines
       is looking to lease more 
        Airbus
       planes, according to a report.  United is seeking the Airbus A321 jet, which competes with Boeing’s 737 MAX family of aircraft, Bloomberg reported Thursday. Any new A321 jets United can get its hands on would likely replace orders for 737 MAX jets. That could include replacements for the 737 MAX 10 jets United has ordered—the 10 is the longest version of the MAX, but isn’t certified for commercial flight yet. Boeing referred Barron’s to United for a comment on a customer’s fleet plans. United Airlines declined to comment. It’s no surprise that United isn’t exactly thrilled with Boeing. United CEO Scott Kirby has expressed frustration with MAX 10 delays, and on Tuesday, he talked about getting more A321 jets at an investor conference. Getting them directly from Airbus doesn’t appear to be an option for United, however, because A321 production is booked out until the end of the decade.  “We’re not going to target an artificial growth rate,” Kirby said at the conference. ”These [planes] are 30-year assets. We wouldn’t, for example, overpay so that we could hit next year’s growth or hit 2026 growth.”  United might have more success getting capacity by turning to aircraft lessors. These companies, like airlines, also order Boeing and Airbus planes. It’s possible lessors have some flexibility that airlines, such as United, can take advantage of, but leasing Airbus models won’t come cheap. Planes are in hot demand, with customers ordering some 2,800 single-aisle jets from Boeing and Airbus in 2023. That was the most since 2006, as far back as Barron’s checked. Boeing plans to build about 38 MAX jets a month in 2024. That’s in line with recent production rates, but is also a cap placed on the company by the Federal Aviation Administration in response to the 737 MAX 9 emergency door plug failure on Jan. 5. Boeing appears to be struggling to maintain that rate. United, 
        Southwest Airlines,
       and 
        Ryanair
       expect fewer MAX deliveries in 2024 than they did a few months ago. Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu calculates about 70 Boeing planes that airlines previously expected now won’t arrive in 2024, so far. Eventually, Boeing plans to get to a production rate of 50 MAX jets a month. Airbus wants to get to 75 A320-family jets a month. Airbus has delivered A320s at a rate of almost 50 a month recently. Deliveries are the best proxy for production that investors can see easily. Both aircraft makers post monthly delivery results.  Ramping production past those levels for either company is a monthslong—even yearslong—process requiring coordination among hundreds of suppliers at multiple levels of the aerospace supply chain.  Boeing stock was up 0.7% in early trading at $182.58. The 
        S&P 500
       and 
        Nasdaq Composite
       were down 0.4% and 0.7%, respectively. Potentially losing orders isn’t good news, but coming into Friday trading, Boeing shares were already down about 31% year to date.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com So far this year, the PHLX Semiconductor Index has increased 8.7% (with dividends reinvested), but it has declined 7.7% in April. Meanwhile, shares of industry star Nvidia Inc. have declined 12% this month.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
United Airlines Is Looking For More Airb.short_description: United Airlines Is Looking For More Airbus Jets. It’s Another Blow for Boeing.

Boeing Jet Production Is Taking a Hit. W.title: Boeing Jet Production Is Taking a Hit. Why That’s Good for GE Stock.
Boeing Jet Production Is Taking a Hit. W.text:
Boeing
       continues to be battered by bad news, sending its shares lower, while stocks of aerospace suppliers look just fine. But if Boeing struggles to produce planes, won’t that eventually hurt its suppliers like 
        General Electric
      ?  The surprising answer—a result of the structure of the industry and the current demand for jets—is no, not really.  Through Thursday trading, Boeing shares were down about 11% over the past week and down about 31% year to date. Most, if not all, of the declines, are linked to production-quality issues uncovered after an emergency-door plug blew out during an 
        Alaska Air
       flight of a 737 MAX 9 on Jan. 5.  The Federal Aviation Administration has capped Boeing 737 MAX production at 38 a month and will require quality improvements before letting output increase. Boeing wants to produce 50 MAX jets a month eventually.  Right now, even 38 looks like a stretch. Boeing only delivered 42 MAX jets in January and February combined, far short of a 38-per-month run rate. Boeing doesn’t disclose monthly production; sales are the best proxy available.   Some production shortfalls are showing up in the airline industry. 
        Southwest Airlines
       now anticipates receiving 46 MAX jets in 2024, down from the 79 it had told investors to expect. 
        Ryanair
       expects roughly 20 fewer deliveries. 
        United Airlines
       will take 70-plus MAX jets, about 20 fewer than Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu expected.  That is roughly 70 “missing planes” she says.  Overall, Wall Street is expecting about 507 MAX jet deliveries in 2024. That is more than 40 a month, but Boeing is still delivering planes built during the worldwide MAX grounding that ran from March 2019 to November 2020. A production rate of 38 jets a month yields 456 for a year, leaving planes made and parked during the grounding to fill the gap.  If Boeing produces 70 jets less than the 456 it would pump out at 38 a month, that would be a 15% reduction in the number of components Boeing’s suppliers could expect to sell. That wouldn’t be good.  But investors can’t find evidence of a mounting problem in share prices. Through Thursday trading, shares of MAX engine supplier General Electric were up more than 30% year to date. Shares of 
        Howmet Aerospace
       were up 21%. And shares of 
        Safran
       and 
        Parker-Hannifin
      —two more aerospace suppliers—were up 26% and 16%, respectively.  Investors aren’t asleep. The market, in this instance, is probably right. The suppliers will be all right.  For starters, 
        Airbus
       is expected to deliver some 800 planes in 2024, up from 735 delivered in 2023. What is more, Boeing is projected to deliver some 140 non-MAX jets. The MAX shortfall is only 5% of all commercial jet deliveries.  Some suppliers have also been more conservative than Boeing’s 38-per-month target. Howmet, for instance, based its 2024 guidance on 34 MAX jets a month.   Even if production gets even worse, Kahyaoglu said, she would still have “zero” concerns about earnings coming from GE. She points out that GE’s financial guidance is partly based on new planes replacing old planes, many of which use GE’s CFM56 engines. Even if the new planes aren’t made right away, the company would still get revenue from servicing the existing engines.  GE Aerospace expects to generate about $6 billion to $6.5 billion in operating profit. GE would do better, according to Kahyaoglu, if retirements of older jets slowed down because fewer MAX jets were built. The aftermarket business earns higher profit margins than the original equipment business.   GE is dividing itself into GE Aerospace and GE Vernova—its power-generation businesses—on April 2. A slightly better outlook for the aerospace aftermarket is one reason shares of aftermarket players 
        Heico,
FTAI Aviation,
       and 
        TransDigm
       were up about 4%, 24%, and 17%, respectively.   GE didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment about how fewer planes being retired would affect its financial guidance. In any case, there is no guarantee that lower plane production would lead to less business for suppliers. Inventory is the reason.  At an investor event on March 7, GE CEO Larry Culp said that Boeing is still taking engine deliveries at the expected rate. It will need the engines eventually—the planes Boeing makes are all sold and expected by customers.  Boeing’s problems don’t change the overall outlook for the commercial aerospace industry. Planes are in hot demand. Customers ordered some 2,800 single-aisle jets from Boeing and Airbus in 2023. That was the most since 2006, as far back as Barron’s checked.  Those orders will keep production lines humming up and down the aerospace value chain for the next few years, at least.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. Boeing Jet Production Is Taking a Hit. W.short_description: Boeing Jet Production Is Taking a Hit. Why That’s Good for GE Stock.

RFK Jr. talks AI and Elon Musk.title: RFK Jr. talks AI and Elon Musk
RFK Jr. talks AI and Elon Musk.text:
Jon Swartz interviewed Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who shared his opinions about artificial intelligence and Elon Musk, as well as other topics. Shares of Nvidia Corp. 
        NVDA,
        +5.59%
       were down 5% for one week through Thursday. Then again, the stock was still up 78% for 2024, after it more than tripled during 2023.  Here is a sampling of recent coverage of Nvidia: In this week’s ETF Wrap, Christine Idzelis looks into the short-term and long-term performance of the $253 billion Invesco QQQ Trust 
        QQQ,
       which tracks the performance of the Nasdaq-100 Index.  QQQ has slightly underperformed the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust 
        SPY
       this year. But for the 10 years through Thursday, QQQ returned 439%, compared with a 237% return for SPY, both with dividends reinvested, according to FactSet. Here is some of this week’s coverage of large technology companies and their stocks: Let’s take a look at two charts showing the price movement for Tesla Inc.’s 
        TSLA,
        -1.20%
       stock. First, five years through Thursday: And now three years: Long-term loyalists are sitting on big gains for Tesla. The stock was up 955% for the 10 years through Thursday and was up 785% for 5 years. But the stock was down 31% for 3 years. And for 2024 through Thursday, Tesla’s shares were down 35%. Among 50 analysts working for brokerage firms who cover Tesla, 18 rate the stock a buy or the equivalent, while 23 have neutral ratings and nine rate the stock a sell or the equivalent, according to FactSet.  Coverage of changing sentiment on Tesla and related news: Investors are wondering what will happen with Fisker Inc. 
        FSR,
       which made 10,193 Ocean electric vehicles in 2023 and set a goal of delivering between 20,000 and 22,000 of the SUVs in 2024. The company’s stock dropped 53%, to close a 15 cents, on Thursday following a report in the Wall Street Journal that it was considering a bankruptcy filing.  Claudia Assis covered Fisker’s reaction to that report and other developments. Other EV-related coverage: Investors are told over and over that time in the stock market beats market timing. If you are making regular contributions into a retirement account that are broadly invested, then you will pay lower prices during down periods for the market, which can enhance returns over the years. But what if you are holding an individual stock? For an example of a lucrative long-term investment and perfectly timed stock sale, Nathan Vardi told the story of Ray Debbane, the former chair of WW International 
        WW,
        +9.12%,
       whose private-equity firm had held 21% of WW’s shares. Debbane announced his departure as chair of WW International a year ago, when his company sold its stake in the company. The stock was down 58% for one year through Thursday. On Tuesday, New York Community Bancorp 
        NYCB,
        -2.61%
       completed the deal under which an investor group led by former U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s private-equity firm provided over $1 billion in capital. The bank then announced it was planning a reverse stock split. New York Community Bancorp also made two more moves to shore up its balance sheet and discussed other operational improvements, as Steve Gelsi reported. Reddit is expected to price its initial public offering of shares next week. Here is coverage from James Rogers: Spring begins next week. Aarthi Swaminathan took a detailed look at the ins and outs of the U.S. housing market. More housing coverage and advice: Beth Pinsker took a detailed look at business deductions to reduce taxable income that were suggested by Tik Tok users. It turns out that this one can be a tricky way to lower your tax bill. More from Beth Pinsker: My mother, 80, owes $400,000 due to a failed family business and my late father’s unpaid taxes. What could be seized? Andrew Keshner explained how some wealthy investors avoid income taxes by holding municipal bonds. A question for the Tax Guy: I made a profit when I sold concert tickets last year. Do I need to report this on my tax return? Quentin Fottrell — the Moneyist — answers difficult questions from readers about money and family relationships. Here are some of his articles from this week: Want more from MarketWatch? Sign up for this and other newsletters to get the latest news and advice on personal finance and investing. Have an issue with your financial adviser or looking for a new one? Switch on cockpit pilot seat may have in.title: Switch on cockpit pilot seat may have inadvertently triggered sudden plunge in Boeing Latam jet: report
Switch on cockpit pilot seat may have in.text:
A switch on a pilot’s seat aboard a Boeing 787 Dreamliner may have caused the flight to suddenly lose altitude, resulting in injuries to several passengers. That’s according to a Thursday report in The Wall Street Journal, which cited U.S. industry officials who had been briefed on a preliminary report about the Latam flight incident that occurred on Monday.  The officials said that the flight attendant had been serving a meal in the cockpit and somehow hit a switch on the pilot’s seat that pushed the pilot into those controls, ultimately leading to a brief nosedive for the plane. That switch is normally covered and not supposed to be in use when a pilot is seated. Flight LA800 bound for Santiago, Chile with 263 passengers and nine crew members departed Sydney for Auckland, New Zealand early Monday, when at some point it briefly plunged, reportedly sending some passengers flying into the air. Around 50 people were treated for mostly mild injuries when the plane landed in Auckland.  The New Zealand Herald quoted an unnamed passenger who described the plane as briefly freezing in midair.  The probe is being led by an accident investigation commission in New Zealand. A Latam spokesman told The Wall Street Journal that the company was cooperating with officials, while Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.30%
       said it was “in contact with our customer…and stands ready to support investigation-related activities as requested,” in a statement.  A Boeing spokeswoman told MarketWatch in an email that the company was deferring to “investigating agencies for any information.” MarketWatch has also reached out to Latam for comment.   The report said that Boeing was due to issue a memo with regards to the seat switch to airlines using the 787 Dreamliner. Boeing has been under scrutiny since the midair blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.60%
       jet in early January. Read: Seat belt saved passenger’s life on Boeing 737 Max that suffered midair blowout, new lawsuit claims The Google parent posts earnings ahead of expectations, helped in part by AI-driven demand for cloud computing. FAA says it\u2019s investigating tire pr.title: FAA says it’s investigating tire problem on American Airlines flight to Los Angeles
FAA says it\u2019s investigating tire pr.text:
FORT WORTH, Texas — Federal officials are investigating after an American Airlines plane flying from Dallas to Los Angeles suffered a tire problem, just a week after a United Airlines jetliner lost a tire during takeoff. The Federal Aviation Administration said Thursday that American Airlines 
        AAL,
        -2.05%
       flight 345 “blew a tire” during takeoff from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. American said, however, that the pilots got a warning of low pressure in one of the tires. The Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.30%
       777 landed safely and taxied to the gate under its own power, American said. That model of plane has 14 tires: six on each of the two main landing-gear assemblies and two more under the nose landing gear. The FAA is also investigating an incident last week in which a United Airlines 
        UAL,
        -1.64%
       Boeing 777 lost a tire during takeoff in San Francisco and cut short a flight to Japan to land safely at Los Angeles International Airport. Both planes in the recent incidents are more than 20 years old. Google parent Alphabet Inc.’s stock soared 12% in after-hours trading Thursday following huge spikes in revenue and net income that trounced analysts’ predictions — as well as its first-ever cash dividend of 20 cents per share. \u2018Run with the bulls.\u2019 Don\u201.title: ‘Run with the bulls.’ Don’t worry about the S&P 500 until it reaches 6,250, says SocGen.
\u2018Run with the bulls.\u2019 Don\u201.text:
A previous version of this article gave an incorrect S&P 500 target level in the headline. The story has been corrected. “The Magnificent Seven story is over, thankfully.” That was Jay Woods, the chief global strategist of Freedom Capital Markets, speaking to CNBC on Wednesday after another down day for most Big Tech names — Tesla 
        TSLA,
        -1.18%
       and Apple 
        AAPL,
        +0.06%
       were hardest hit, and the Nasdaq Composite is clinging to a roughly 0.5% monthly gain.  Concerns the tech run is getting stretched — even over — come as bitcoin scales new heights, with JPMorgan recently flagging that as a potential sign of froth in overall markets. Meanwhile, sentiment surveys from the American Association of Individual Investors cited “unusually high” optimism for the retail crowd. Also see: Retail traders last week rotated into Apple and Boeing, away from Nvidia But “run with the bulls,” says our call of the day from Société Générale’s head of U.S. equity strategy, Manish Kabra, who points to a trifecta of signals suggesting stocks are some ways from overexuberance. “To cut a long story short, it’s about profit inflection,” Kabra said in a recent note. “The S&P 500 has clear room to overshoot despite trading at 21 times forward price/earnings as the new highs on the index coincide with new highs in the profit cycle.” SocGen has penciled in 5% earnings growth in 2024 and 15% for 2025, and all of that is “exposed to upside risk,” the strategist says.  “The tech-heavy Nasdaq-100 is still the most important driver and source of the EPS [earnings per share] cycle. Our TMT bubble maths suggest the S&P 500 would need to reach 6,250 to tip over into irrational exuberance from current rational optimism,” he says.  They found that during the 2000 boom, tech traded at 2 times its profit share in the S&P 500 
        SPX
       and the Nasdaq-100 is currently at 1.25 times per share. The S&P 500 itself traded at 25 times 12 months forward price/earnings during that boom versus the current 21 times.  “We say stay long U.S. tech, as the profit cycle should accelerate further in [the first half], and stay long industrials on reshoring and redistrubtion of global supply chains,” said Kabra, who also said their tech AI Rise of Robots theme is a favorable investing spot.  As for his three turning-point signals, SG’s Global Cycle Indicator, fed by OECD leading economic indicators, points to a “boom” market regime as it remains on an uptrend that began in April 2023.  “The breadth of the indicator signals that 76% of countries’ leading economic indicators have improved over the past six months and 65% have improved over the past 12 months,” he said.  The second signal — SocGen’s Consumer Composite Indicator, driven by consumer confidence, housing and employment trends — remains positive after a turn in January, due to strong U.S. housing growth, he says. Finally, the SG Cross Asset Momentum Indicator has been positive for eight straight weeks. Beyond the EPS cycle hitting new highs, Kabresh sees U.S. stocks supported by high-yield spread compression — when yield differences between safe assets like Treasuries and high-yield corporate bonds narrow.  Calm conditions for junk bonds indicate debt investors aren’t worried about company prospects, which is stock-supportive.  “Substantial room” for fixed income volatility to come down is also a plus, says the strategist. “This backdrop should not lead to derating of U.S. equities beyond technical price reversals,” he says. SocGen set a 4,750 target for the S&P 500 in September, which is middle of Wall Street forecasts for this year, some of which have since been bumped up. Retail traders rotated into underperform.title: Retail traders rotated into underperformers Apple and Boeing, away from surging Nvidia
Retail traders rotated into underperform.text:
Is now the time to pounce on the stock of Apple and Boeing? Retail traders seem to think so, according to an analysis of trading last week from JPMorgan. Apple 
        AAPL,
        +0.06%
       saw the highest retail net turnover, of $1.43 billion, and Boeing  
        BA,
        +0.34%
       also was a top ten stock for net retail inflow. Retail traders also snapped up Broadcom 
        AVGO,
        +3.91%,
       Alphabet  
        GOOGL,
        +10.12%
       and Novo Nordisk 
        NVO,
        +0.87%.
 By contrast, retail money moved away from Advanced Micro Devices 
        AMD,
        +2.26%,
       Nvidia  
        NVDA,
        +5.76%
       and Meta Platforms 
        META,
        +0.50%,
       which all have surged this year, according to the JPMorgan data.  Apple’s stock has struggled this year, pressured in particular by reports iPhone sales have skidded in China amid lukewarm interest and intense competition. Boeing has been dogged by an array of manufacturing and legal issues. Read: NTSB says Boeing doesn’t know who handled panel that blew off 737 Max jet By contrast, Nvidia’s stock has surged as the chipmaker fuels artificial intelligence computing needed for large language models. Overall, retail traders bought $3.9 billion of equities, nearly a full standard deviation about the 12 month average. While analyst Peng Cheng said there was “sluggish” interest in the S&P 500 
        SPY
       and Nasdaq-100 
        QQQ
       exchange-traded funds, demand for bitcoin ETFs continued to be strong, particularly the iShares Bitcoin Trust 
        IBIT
       and the Fidelity Wise Origin Bitcoin Fund 
        FBTC.
 JPMorgan relies on a methodology that focuses on transactions routed to wholesalers to identify retail trades.
