Tesla and Boeing Are the Worst Stocks in.title: Tesla and Boeing Are the Worst Stocks in the S&P 500 This Year. They’re Paying for Decisions Made Years Ago.
Tesla and Boeing Are the Worst Stocks in.text:
Tesla
       and 
        Boeing
       stocks are the worst in the S&P 500 this year, and while that may feel random it actually tells a story about investing, strategy, and psychology.  Through Wednesday’s trading, Tesla stock was down about 31% this year, while Boeing shares declined about 30%, making the pair the worst performers in the entire 
        S&P 500.
       The S&P 500, overall, was up about 8% year to date.  Through a market-mathematical lens, those gains and losses make sense. Earnings drive stock prices and earnings estimates for the entire S&P 500 are up roughly 7% since late December, according to Bloomberg. Those higher earnings estimates resulted in higher equity values and the change in the index closely mirrored the change in estimates.  Earnings estimates for Boeing and Tesla aren’t going up. For the EV maker, analysts have cut their 2024 and 2025 earnings estimates by 21% and 25%, respectively. Boeing’s 2024 earnings estimates are down about 26% since late December. The 2025 hit hasn’t been as severe though, falling about 9%.  Boeing’s estimates are headed lower amid higher regulatory scrutiny and lower production after repeated quality problems which culminated in a door plug flying out of a new Boeing jet in flight. Boeing customers are likely as frustrated as the company with slower production. Demand for new aircraft is near record levels with air travel finally eclipsing prepandemic levels.  Tesla, on the other hand, isn’t having quality manufacturing problems. It’s facing slowing demand growth for electric vehicles amid more competition while rolling out an aging product lineup. Telsa’s best-selling Model Y was introduced in 2020. On the surface, Boeing and Tesla’s problems look different, but they have a similar root. Both companies are living with strategic mistakes made years ago. Shareholders are only grasping the missteps now.   In the case of Boeing, the seeds of the current problem were sown in 2011 when it announced the 737 MAX, a modified 737, in response to the growing success of the 
        Airbus
       A320neo family of jets.  Aviation consultants and analysts still debate whether Boeing should have designed an all-new plane versus another modification of a plane in service for more than 55 years. Many wish Boeing went with the more expensive and lengthier all-new option, but it went with the latter and shareholders are paying for that decision in 2024.  In the case of Tesla, a prototype of the avant-garde Cybertruck was unveiled in 2019, giving it priority over a lower-cost vehicle. At the time, the decision seemed sound. EV pricing wasn’t a concern and full-size trucks make up a large portion of new car sales in the U.S. Today, the decision doesn’t look as smart. The Cybertruck is expensive and hard to build. And 
        BYD
       has become the largest seller of all-battery electric vehicles—mainly by offering lower-priced EVs, while Tesla has nothing to offer car buyers in the sub-$30,000 price category.  The market doesn’t realize mistakes all at once. Boeing stock was roughly $440 a share in March 2019, years after the MAX launch and after one tragic crash of Boeing’s MAX jet. Tesla stock was north of $400 a share in November 2021, two years after the Cybertruck launch and about three years after CEO Elon Musk believed Teslas would drive themselves without any supervision. Boeing closed at $182.35 Wednesday, while Tesla closed at $169.48. Market psychology is such that successful companies get a long rope. Investors are inherently optimistic. But when they stop being optimistic things go bad in what feels like the blink of an eye.  Today, both companies are in the ‘Show me’ phase of the market’s psychology. No longer do Elon Musk’s predictions about Tesla’s future market capitalization topping that of 
        Apple
       and Saudi Aramco combined boost his company’s stock. And for Boeing, investors ignore new orders and sell stock after every potential problem. Both companies have to win back investor trust. For Boeing, that means demonstrating improved quality as production ramps higher. For Tesla, it means new, attractive vehicles developed on a schedule—and new vehicles regardless of progress made on its self-driving car technology. In short, both companies need to address mistakes of the past and then wait for those decisions to bear fruit. A cheaper Tesla is due in 2025. Boeing still hasn’t decided to develop a new jet.  By the way, the best-performing shares in the S&P 500 year to date belong to 
        Nvidia.
       That tells a story too. Investors are hungry for exposure to the artificial intelligence boom. That, however, is another story.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com So far this year, the PHLX Semiconductor Index has increased 8.7% (with dividends reinvested), but it has declined 7.7% in April. Meanwhile, shares of industry star Nvidia Inc. have declined 12% this month.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Tesla and Boeing Are the Worst Stocks in.short_description: Tesla and Boeing Are the Worst Stocks in the S&P 500 This Year. They’re Paying for Decisions Made Years Ago.

NTSB says Boeing doesn\u2019t know who h.title: NTSB says Boeing doesn’t know who handled panel that blew off 737 Max jet
NTSB says Boeing doesn\u2019t know who h.text:
The nation’s chief accident investigator said Wednesday that her agency still doesn’t know who worked on the panel that blew off a jetliner in January and that Boeing’s CEO told her that he couldn’t provide the information because the company has no records about the job. “The absence of those records will complicate the NTSB’s investigation moving forward,” National Transportation Safety Board Chair Jennifer Homendy wrote in a letter to a Senate committee that is looking into the Jan. 5 accident on a Boeing 737 Max 9 operated by Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.48%.
 Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.29%
       issued a brief statement vowing, as it has many times, to support the investigation. Homendy told senators last week that the NTSB asked Boeing for security-camera footage that might help identify who worked on the panel in September, but was told the video was overwritten after 30 days — months before the blowout. Boeing said Wednesday that it’s standard company practice to erase video after 30 days. Homendy’s latest letter to the Senate Commerce Committee was a follow-up to her appearance before the panel last week. Shortly after her testimony ended, Boeing provided names of 25 employees who work on doors at the company’s 737 factory near Seattle. She said, however, the company still hasn’t said which of the workers removed the panel, which plugs a hole left when extra emergency doors are not required on a plane. She said she even called Boeing CEO David Calhoun. “He stated he was unable to provide that information and maintained that Boeing has no records of the work being performed,” Homendy wrote. Boeing did not comment on the phone call. There is a drawback to NTSB’s focus on identifying specific workers, Homendy conceded. She worried that it could discourage people from talking about the matter with investigators, and so she told her staff to protect the identities of Boeing employees who come forward. NTSB says Boeing doesn\u2019t know who h.short_description: NTSB says Boeing doesn’t know who handled panel that blew off 737 Max jet

Boeing bonds are still coveted by invest.title: Boeing bonds are still coveted by investors despite a rough 2024 for jet maker
Boeing bonds are still coveted by invest.text:
Investors may have soured on Boeing Co.’s stock, but not on the aerospace and defense company’s bonds, which on Wednesday were seeing a wave of buying activity from Wall Street investors.  So far in 2024, Boeing’s 
        BA,
        +0.29%
       bonds have seen about $209 million more in buying from customers than sales, according to data from BondCliQ. The buying in Boeing debt comes as spreads — the extra compensation investors earn on bonds above a risk-free benchmark — have generally increased by about 15 basis points in the past week, according to BondCliQ data.  That had Boeing’s shorter-dated bonds maturing in 2027 at roughly a 5.4% yield, while those due in 2060 were closer to a 6.4% yield.  Those levels compared with a roughly 5.35% yield for the broader U.S. investment-grade corporate-bond market. Boeing has faced a slew of quality problems and snags in recent months, including the high-profile midair blowout of a panel on an Alaska Airlines jet in early January, which has led to heightened scrutiny from aviation authorities.   The company on Tuesday reported February deliveries that put the jet maker further behind last year’s sales pace and did little to ease worries about its first-quarter sales. Southwest Airlines Co. 
        LUV,
        -0.94%,
       which exclusively flies Boeing 737s, said in a filing Tuesday that Boeing has told it to expect only 46 Max jets to be delivered this year, from a previous expectation of 79 Max planes. Given the reduced expected deliveries for 2024, CreditSights analysts said they see several quarters ahead where Boeing could end up operating below its $10 billion minimum cash balance.  That potentially could trigger credit-rating downgrades, the analysts said, but still keep the company in the BBB credit-ratings bracket, or a few steps above the junk-bond category.   Boeing is in talks to buy supplier Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc.
SPR,
        +2.37%
       as it seeks to improve quality controls. Spirit AeroSystems makes fuselages and other jet components for Boeing, which in 2005 sold the assets that became Spirit AeroSystems. Boeing’s stock has lost 10% in the last 12 months, and 30% so far this year. That contrasts with an advance of 23% and 8%, respectively, for the S&P 500 index 
        SPX
       over those same periods. The Google parent posts earnings ahead of expectations, helped in part by AI-driven demand for cloud computing. Claudia Assis is a San Francisco-based reporter for MarketWatch. Follow her on Twitter @ClaudiaAssisMW. Joy Wiltermuth is a news editor and senior markets reporter based in San Francisco. FTC chief blasts Boeing for \u2018monopo.title: FTC chief blasts Boeing for ‘monopolization,’ says company has become ‘too big to fail’
FTC chief blasts Boeing for \u2018monopo.text:
““Boeing effectively became too-big-to-fail and a point of leverage for countries seeking to influence policymaking.””
 That’s Federal Trade Commission Chair Lina Khan, noting that few American companies have struggled as mightily as Boeing over the past five years, and placing some of the blame at the feet of U.S. policymakers.  She criticized her predecessors for allowing a historic wave of consolidation in the aerospace industry starting in the 1980s, which left Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.28%
       as the nation’s only commercial aerospace manufacture following its 1997 merger with rival McDonnel Douglas.   Read more: Boeing vows changes after government audit finds lapses in manufacturing quality Khan said that Boeing is an example of a company that has promoted itself as a ”national champion” which must be shielded from antitrust enforcement because its success is important for America’s success on the global stage. “Boeing is the clearest example of a purposeful decision to bet on national champions on behalf of American interests,” Khan said Wednesday at a speech on the future of American innovation at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.  The company is ”the single best example of why a national champion strategy can be catastrophic,” she added.      Khan said that Boeing’s current struggles are a prime example of the harms caused by “monopolization,” which lead to lower quality products, short-sighted cost cutting and overwhelming political power.  “Boeing effectively became too-big-to-fail and a point of leverage for countries seeking to influence policymaking,” Khan argued, noting that Congress “carved out a $25 billion line item” for Boeing during the COVID crisis.   Boeing was able to forgo that money and issue bonds to raise the needed cash in 2020, though analysts say Federal Reserve support of corporate bond markets at the time was an important factor in the company’s ability to raise money privately.  See also: Boeing’s February deliveries slow down amid Max uncertainty Khan said the example of Boeing should be instructive as some technology companies have argued that pursuing antitrust cases against them or otherwise regulating them will “weaken the American innovation and cede  the global stage to China.”  On the contrary, Khan argued, it was tough antitrust enforcement against the leading tech companies of the 1970s like AT&T 
        T,
        +1.12%
       and Kodak 
        KODK,
        +2.39%
       that created openings for Silicon Valley entrepreneurs to mount the information technology revolution in the subsequent decades.  “The reality is that some of these same firms are fairly integrated into China and are seeking greater access to the Chinese markets,” she said. “If America’s dominant firms are not prioritizing America’s national interests, what should we make of the idea that they can keep American in the lead if they’re left alone?” Consumer sentiment deteriorated near the end of April, according to the latest reading from the University of Michigan. FTC chief blasts Boeing for \u2018monopo.short_description: FTC chief blasts Boeing for ‘monopolization,’ says company has become ‘too big to fail’

Tesla now worth less than JPMorgan as st.title: Tesla now worth less than JPMorgan as stock slapped with new bearish call
Tesla now worth less than JPMorgan as st.text:
Shares of Tesla Inc. extended their selloff toward a 10-month low Wednesday, as a Wells Fargo analyst moved to a bearish stance on the stock. With Wednesday’s 3.6% move lower in afternoon trading, Tesla 
        TSLA,
        -1.19%
       is set to end the day below JPMorgan Chase & Co. 
        JPM,
        +0.18%
       in terms of market capitalization. Tesla was worth $544.9 billion based on Wednesday’s intraday action, while JPMorgan was worth $551.1 billion. Tesla would be the 12th largest U.S. public company by market cap.  Despite seeming like a growth company, Tesla’s business has been nearly flat in the European Union and China over the last 12 months, while its U.S. business has been down since the second quarter, Wells Fargo’s Colin Langan noted in his downgrade. He cut his rating on Tesla’s stock to underweight from equal weight Wednesday. Tesla shares are off 31.2% on a year-to-date basis in a downward move that’s wiped out about $246.5 billion from the company’s market capitalization. The electric vehicle giant’s stock is now the S&P 500 index’s 
        SPX
       worst performer this year, as it surpassed the 29.9% selloff in Boeing Co.’s stock 
        BA,
        +0.26%.
 In comparison, the Global X Autonomous & Electric Vehicles ETF 
        DRIV
       has slipped 1.1% this year and the S&P 500 has gained 8.5%. Even with the recent underperformance, Langan sees multiple headwinds in the company’s future, including the potential for more pressure on volumes since price cuts don’t seem to be as effective as they once were. Langan also wonders if the company’s next big vehicle — the Model 2 expected out in the second half of 2025 — will live up to the hype given competition in its target market and the possibility of launch delays. He cut his price target on the stock to $125 from $200, with the new target implying the potential for 28% downside from current levels.  But Tesla’s stock found a defender elsewhere, as Wedbush analyst Dan Ives did his best to support the electric-vehicle giant by saying negative investor sentiment is “way overdone.” Ives said the current bearish narrative is similar to those seen a number of times over the years, when doubters ended up getting proven wrong after saying that Tesla’s time to shine was over and EVs were just a fad. And while Ives said EV demand has clearly moderated, he expects sales and profitability to improve in the coming quarters. “Now is not the time to throw in the towel on Tesla…we have a high level of conviction at current levels despite the dark black clouds forming,” Ives wrote in a note to clients. Wedbush’s Ives reiterated his buy rating on the stock and his $315 price target, which implies about 84% upside from current levels. Ives is part of the minority on Wall Street, as only 18 of the 50 analysts surveyed by FactSet who cover Tesla are bullish. Meanwhile, 23 are neutral and the number of bears increased to nine with Langan’s downgrade. Ives acknowledged that the EV price wars in China are “brutal,” but he said there is a sense that many price cuts are starting to subside into the spring and summer, which is good news for both Tesla and the EV industry. He said demand is “sluggish” for the first quarter and the “noise” around Chief Executive Elon Musk’s $56 billion compensation package is a negative overhang on the stock. However, Ives wrote, “the stock is way overshooting on the negative front as the demand story for Tesla is more in stabilization mode heading to the rest of 2024, price cuts are moderating, battery costs/production is showing strong cost efficiencies, and a Model 2 (sub $30K vehicle) is on the roadmap for the next year.”  He said the stock’s risk-versus-reward profile is “extremely compelling” at current prices. Ives envisions a valuation for Tesla exceeding $1 trillion, compared with the current market cap of $565.4 billion, as the artificial-intelligence and full-self-driving programs are making “major strides” at the company. Read: Tesla’s Autopilot, other driver-assistance systems get poor ratings from auto-insurance group. Also read: Tesla’s stock chart sends warning to bears that momentum may have bottomed. “The demand story for EVs globally has clearly moderated, however we believe Tesla is on the broader trajectory to see growth and margin improvement return to the story over the coming quarters,” Ives wrote. Southwest Airlines Co.’s stock tumbled 9% Thursday after the airline posted a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and revenue that lagged estimates. Tomi Kilgore is MarketWatch's deputy investing and corporate news editor and is based in New York. You can follow him on Twitter @TomiKilgore. How Safe Are Boeing Planes? A Look at th.title: How Safe Are Boeing Planes? A Look at the Data.
How Safe Are Boeing Planes? A Look at th.text:
Boeing
       stock has been battered by legitimate quality concerns—and by endless headlines re-examining the same issues while raising any incident involving a Boeing jet to a potential stock-moving event. It’s overwhelming.  No one these days can win an argument about the soundness of Boeing’s quality and manufacturing processes. Still, many recent reports involving Boeing jets don’t qualify as unusual. The good news for investors is Boeing jets, overall, perform well in service—about as well as other aircraft makers. The bad news is that doesn’t mean Boeing stock will go up. That will depend on Boeing’s quality improvement, evidenced by the Federal Aviation Administration loosening its grip on the airplane maker.  The FAA has capped 737 MAX production at 38 a month. Eventually, Boeing wants to produce 50 a month. Boeing has to demonstrate better quality control before it’s allowed to ramp production.  Better stock performance will also require investors to become more savvy about filtering incidents involving commercial jets. That requires some context about what is normal in the aerospace business.  For starters, the Federal Aviation Administration Accident and Incident database tracked 198 U.S. incidents involving Boeing aircraft over the 10 years from 2014 to 2023 compared with 99 for 
        Airbus.
 It makes some sense that Boeing has more incidents than Airbus. U.S. airlines fly more Boeing jets. Today, about 51% of the planes in U.S.-based airline fleets are Boeing jets. Airbus jets account for about 28% of the total with 
        Embraer
       and 
        Bombardier
       regional jets accounting for about 14% and 7%, respectively.  The FAA data show there hasn’t been much change in the number of incidents from year to year and that commercial jets in the U.S. have one or two recordable incidents every month. Anything can be an incident—from a bump while taxiing to problems in flight.   The FAA database isn’t a definitive list of incidents. It’s only one source. The National Transportation Safety Board database has more data, including international incidents.  The NTSB database, for instance, includes the two tragic 737 MAX crashes occurring overseas in October 2018 and March 2019. Those crashes claimed 348 lives and resulted in the worldwide grounding of all MAX jets for almost two years while Boeing worked to fix faulty flight control software. The NTSB database also includes the tragic 2014 Malaysia Airlines flight that was shot down by Russian forces over Ukraine.  NTSB data show commercial airliners around the world have about three reportable incidents a month. Over the past decade, that data works out to one incident—of any kind—every 200,000 flights. The International Civil Aviation Organization, another source on aviation safety, reports the global aviation industry reports about two accidents per million flights. That’s down from about three a decade ago.  The difference between incidents and accidents boils down to what data each organization collects. The 2023 ICAO report listed 64 accidents occurring in 2022. The NTSB database tracked 165 incidents tied to major aircraft makers that year.  Many of the incidents the NTSB collects have nothing to do with aircraft maintenance or design. Many involve older aircraft. The wheel that fell off a 
        United Airlines
       Boeing 777 jet on Mar 7 was 22 years old. That plane had gone through several maintenance checks and inspections over its life.   Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard worries about overreactions when coverage of accidents ramps up without context. “What I think is relevant is the FAA stuff,” he says.  Investors shouldn’t react, as much, to reports of wheels falling off an older plane or 787 turbulence that injured 50 on a LATAM flight. They should pay closer attention to things like the Mar. 11 airworthiness directive which instructs airlines to inspect 737 MAX “spoiler wire bundles that led to unintended spoiler motion.” The spoilers are on the wings and disrupt airflow. Boeing didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment about the airworthiness directive.  Stallard rates shares Hold and has a $230 price target for Boeing stock. “There seemed to be a buyer for Boeing at $200, but even he has given up,” he adds. Stallard believes shares could fall to $180 as the FAA will continue to contain Boeing’s production while it waits for quality metrics to improve.  Boeing stock closed at $184.24 on Tuesday, down 4.3%, after the New York Times provided additional details about a six-week audit conducted by the FAA. The FAA had already reported on Mar. 4 it found “multiple instances” of quality control problems. FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker reviewed some audit findings in a Monday news briefing, saying his agency found issues with paperwork, tool management, and the order work was being done, among other things. “The area between $170 and $176 would be the next stop,” says CappThesis founder and market technician Frank Cappelleri, adding “$176 was the October 2023 low.”  Cappelleri isn’t making a fundamental call on the stock. He is looking at stock charts to get a sense of when Stallard’s “buyer” might get interested again.  Additional declines aren’t what investors want to hear about. The good news, amid a lot of troubling news, is that traveling by plane is still getting safer over time.  That might not be much comfort to Boeing shareholders who have watched the stock fall almost 60% from record highs set in March 2019, while the 
        S&P 500
       is up about 80% over the same span. Still, understanding the safety data can help shareholders understand what new issues that arise matter for their investment.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com Oversold rally earlier this week doesn’t erase the U.S.  market’s negative picture. How Safe Are Boeing Planes? A Look at th.short_description: How Safe Are Boeing Planes? A Look at the Data.

TikTok Is the Latest U.S.-China Battlegr.title: TikTok Is the Latest U.S.-China Battleground, What Investors Should Watch for Next. And 5 Other Things to Know Before Markets Open.
TikTok Is the Latest U.S.-China Battlegr.text:
The uproar in Congress over popular Chinese-owned social-media platform TikTok represents a steady evolution of tension between the world’s two biggest economies. It won’t be the last chapter. On a day when the House of Representatives votes on a bill seeking to ban TikTok in the U.S., or at least force it to sever ties with its Chinese parent ByteDance, the issue underscores the value of big data—not just for marketing, but for national security. The concern among lawmakers is that TikTok may be able to give the data harvested from its millions of users to someone else—the Chinese government, for example. That information could then be used for nefarious purposes—for example spying or extortion. TikTok denies that it is an agent of the Chinese state or any other, and says it poses no greater risk to the U.S. than YouTube or Instagram, owned by 
        Alphabet
       and 
        Meta Platforms
       respectively—two American companies. Still, it isn’t a crazy idea. Anyone who’s seen an advertisement pop up on their phone for a product they might have casually talked about with friends understands how intrusive modern-day technology can be.  To be fair, an app as widespread as TikTok might have become a worry for U.S. officials even if it were owned by a close ally such as the U.K. or Japan. But the reason it’s a problem now is because of the emerging economic rivalry with China. It’s a natural extension of then-president Donald Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs in 2018. That quickly moved on to semiconductors and telecoms equipment. The next flashpoint could be any area where there’s a gap between the two countries and room for one of them to play catch-up. Electric vehicles, as exemplified by the growing competition between 
        Tesla
       and 
        BYD,
       come to mind. So do pharmaceuticals, or renewable energy. When the next front of the trade wars opens there’s certain to be opportunities for savvy investors. —Brian Swint Lawmakers are set to vote today on a bipartisan bill that would force China’s ByteDance to shed its ownership of the popular video-sharing app TikTok within months or risk being blocked on U.S. app stores, something TikTok says amounts to a ban of the social-media app.  What’s Next: The bill needs two-thirds approval in the House to pass. It faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where Democrats hold a slim majority, but President Joe Biden has said he would sign it. —Liz Moyer The Biden administration plans to send up to $300 million worth of weapons to Ukraine, including air defense interceptors, artillery rounds, and armor systems. The funds are coming from money the government saved from contracts that came in under bid, but national security adviser Jake Sullivan says it won’t last long. What’s Next: Sullivan told reporters at a White House briefing that the funding announced Tuesday isn’t a replacement for the foreign aid package, urging Congress to pass one as soon as possible. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell also encouraged the speaker to allow a vote. —Janet H. Cho Dividend payments from U.S. firms rose 5.1% in 2023 to a record $602.1 billion, according to research from money management firm Janus Henderson Global. And it wasn’t just in America—boosting dividends was a global phenomenon with worldwide payouts rising 5% to an all-time high of $1.66 trillion. What’s Next: So what lies ahead for 2024? Probably even more dividend increases. Janus Henderson said it expects another 5% jump in global payouts, to a fresh record of $1.72 trillion this year. “Strong dividend growth in the U.S. during the fourth quarter of 2023 coupled with healthy corporate balance sheets bode well for future dividend growth,” said Amber Milam, client portfolio manager at Janus Henderson, in the report. —Paul R. La Monica Airlines are reducing their schedules and paring back hiring plans after 
        Boeing
       said it would deliver fewer planes than it expected this year. Boeing said it shipped 17 narrow-body MAX jets in February, eight fewer than in January, and half as many deliveries as in November and December. What’s Next: Boeing, which said production would fall below its 38 planes-a-month target in the first half of this year, has unveiled new measures to improve quality, including compliance checks and quality audits at its factory, and an end to performing manufacturing steps out of sequence. —Janet H. Cho, Al Root, and Angela Palumbo 
New York Community Bancorp
       said it is planning a 1-for-3 reverse stock split after completing a deal that gave the regional lender a $1.05 billion capital infusion from an investor group led by former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s private-equity firm. The investor group will hold 39.6% of the company. What’s Next: NYCB is expected to make an amended annual filing later this week as an update to the material weakness disclosure, including its plan for remediating the weaknesses. —Emily Dattilo and Janet H. Cho Dear Quentin, I am requesting advice on behalf of my 24-year-old daughter. She asked me if she should speak up about receiving a smaller raise than a man who is basically the male version of her. Here is the backstory: She is an engineer, and one of the few women at the company in that position. She said the company has difficulty holding onto female engineers, and the women who have left have all cited sexism as a main reason for leaving, and the older women still there have given her numerous examples as cautionary tales.  She found out that a man in her shoes (same degree, same year-end evaluation rating) received a higher raise than she did. She is rather peeved about it, because she was stronger academically than him, so she feels if anything, her raise should be higher, not the other way around. They both have the same degree and graduated at the same time, and they both received the same rating/classification in the year-end review.  She said the man tried to explain it away as there being other factors, such as project funding, that go into raises, but it isn’t sitting right with her.  —The Mother Read the Moneyist’s response here. —Quentin Fottrell —Newsletter edited by Liz Moyer, Patrick O’Donnell, Rupert Steiner Oversold rally earlier this week doesn’t erase the U.S.  market’s negative picture. U.K. Economy Returned to Growth in Janua.title: U.K. Economy Returned to Growth in January -- Update
U.K. Economy Returned to Growth in Janua.text:
By Ed Frankl The U.K. economy returned to growth in January, after contracting in the second half of last year, as rising real wages boosted spending by British shoppers. Britain's economy was weaker than most of its peers last year, and was the only member of the Group of Seven large rich countries to see a contraction in both of the final two quarters. A sustained return to growth would add to signs that global growth is becoming more broadly spread, after being largely driven by the U.S. last year. Gross domestic product in the U.K. rose by 0.2% compared with December, according to figures published Wednesday by the Office for National Statistics, marginally more than the 0.1% expected by economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. In December, the economy contracted by 0.1%. "Big picture: the economy is starting to turn a corner," said Sanjay Raja, Deutsche Bank's chief U.K. economist. As elsewhere in Europe, British consumers were hit hard by the surge in energy and food prices that followed Russia's invasion of Ukraine. But wages are now rising more rapidly than consumer prices, restoring some of that lost spending power. ONS figures released Tuesday showed that real wages--which adjusts pay rises for inflation--were 1.8% higher in the three months through January than a year earlier. Some households have also benefited from tax cuts announced in November, with more to come from next month. However, the economy remains in a weak state. The ONS said GDP in the period from November through January was 0.1% lower than in the three months through October. The Bank of England expects to see growth of just 0.25% this year, although many economists think that is too pessimistic. The government's budget watchdog last week forecast the economy would grow by 0.8%. With growth set to remain modest, investors continue to expect that the BOE will lower its key interest rate this year. "Despite a positive start to the year, the U.K. economy remains in a relatively fragile position," said Roger Barker, director of policy at the Institute of Directors, a lobby group for businesses. "The case for an early cut in interest rates by the Bank of England is still a strong one." While the annual rate of inflation has fallen sharply over recent months, and might reach the central bank's 2% target as early as April, policy makers worry that the still rapid pace of wage rises will keep prices for services rising faster than their target for many months to come. Write to Ed Frankl at edward.frankl@wsj.com JPMorgan, Walmart, and others are using the technologies to become more efficient.. That should help their stocks for the long run. Boeing vows changes after government aud.title: Boeing vows changes after government audit finds lapses in manufacturing quality
Boeing vows changes after government aud.text:
Responding to a U.S. government audit, Boeing said Tuesday that it would work with employees found to have violated company manufacturing procedures to make sure they understand instructions for their jobs. The aircraft maker detailed its latest steps to correct lapses in quality in a memo to employees from Stan Deal, president of Boeing’s commercial plane division. The memo went out after the Federal Aviation Administration finished a six-week review of the company’s manufacturing processes for the 737 Max jetliner after a panel blew off one of the planes during an Alaska Airlines flight in January. The FAA reviewed 89 aspects of production at Boeing’s 
        BA,
        +0.20%
       plant in Renton, Wash., and found the company failed 33 of them, according to a person familiar with the report. The person spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss details that have not been publicly released – although they were reported earlier by the New York Times, which saw a slide presentation on the government’s audit. “The vast majority” of violations found by the FAA involved workers not following Boeing’s approved procedures, Deal said in his memo. Read more: Boeing’s February deliveries slow down amid Max uncertainty Deal said the company will take remedial steps that include “working with each employee noted with a non-compliance during the audit to ensure they fully understand the work instructions and procedures.” Boeing will also add weekly compliance checks for all work teams in the Renton factory, where Max jets are assembled, he said. Deal acknowledged a recent conclusion by a panel of government and industry experts that found Boeing’s procedures for ensuring safety were too complicated and changed too often. “Our teams are working to simplify and streamline our processes and address the panel’s recommendations,” he told staff. Boeing faces a Justice Department investigation into whether its recent problems — including the Jan. 5 blowout of an emergency door panel from an Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.53%
       jet that had taken off from Portland, Ore. — violate terms of a settlement the company reached in 2021 to avoid criminal prosecution after two crashes of Max jets in 2018 in Indonesia and 2019 in Ethiopia killed 346 people. Shares of Arlington, Va.,-based Boeing Co. fell more than 4% on Tuesday. Also read: Boeing whistleblower reportedly found dead in South Carolina JPMorgan, Walmart, and others are using the technologies to become more efficient.. That should help their stocks for the long run. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.

Boeing Stock Falls Again. The Bad News J.title: Boeing Stock Falls Again. The Bad News Just Keeps Piling Up.
Boeing Stock Falls Again. The Bad News J.text:
Boeing
       stock was falling again Tuesday after details emerged regarding the Federal Aviation Administration’s six-week audit of the aerospace company. Analysts are weighing in regarding its problems. A review of the findings of the audit, conducted after the midair blowout of an emergency-door plug on a Boeing 737 MAX 9 jet on Jan. 5, was published by the New York Times on Monday. Boeing failed 33 of 89 so-called product audits conducted by the FAA, the newspaper said.  Investors knew the audit didn’t paint Boeing in a positive light. A Mar. 4 FAA news release noted “multiple instances” of quality control problems. And FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker reviewed some audit findings in a Monday news briefing, saying his agency found issues with paperwork, tool management, and the order work was being done, among other things.  The FAA didn’t respond to a request for comment about the New York Times report. Boeing said, “Based on the FAA audit, our quality [meetings], and the recent expert panel report, we continue to implement immediate changes and develop a comprehensive action plan to strengthen safety and quality and build the confidence of our customers and their passengers.”  The company also outlined steps taken since the audits including inspections of employee toolboxes, adding training, and implementing additional layers of inspections and compliance checks, among other things.   “It all adds up to a pretty big problem,” said AeroDynamic Advisory managing director Richard Aboulafia. “The company’s position, in terms of market share, reputation, and relations with regulators is getting worse.”  The mounting problems continue to weigh on Boeing stock, which dropped 4.3% in Tuesday trading to $184.24. They fell 3% on Monday following a report by The Wall Street Journal that the Justice Department had opened a criminal probe into the Jan. 5 incident. Boeing declined to comment on the report.  The 
        S&P 500
       and 
        Dow Jones Industrial Average
       closed up 1.1% and 0.6%, respectively. Coming into Tuesday’s trading, Boeing stock was down about 26% this year.  The issues for investors didn’t stop at the FAA audit on Tuesday. Separately, 
        Southwest Airlines
       said that it expects to receive 46 Boeing MAX 8 jets in 2024, down from the 58 it had anticipated. The airline said it no longer expects any of the shorter MAX 7 jets it had ordered to be delivered in 2024. The MAX 7 hasn’t been certified by aviation regulators yet.  “Pressure mounting,” wrote Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu in a Tuesday report, citing all the recent news and adding that Boeing recently sent a letter to Washington Democratic Sen. Maria Cantwell—chair of the Senate committee, Science and Transportation—saying it couldn’t find documentation on work performed on the door plug that blew out. Boeing didn’t immediately comment on its correspondence with the senator.   “Aviation Week…notes that the FAA published a notification yesterday that requires 737 operators to check specific wire bundles on their planes,” added Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard in a Tuesday report.  Kahyaoglu rates shares Buy and has a $300 price target for the stock. Stallard rates shares Hold and has a $230 price target.  Overall, 69% of analysts covering the company rate shares Buy, according to FactSet. The average Buy-rating ratio for shares in the S&P 500 is about 55%. The average analyst target price for Boeing stock is about $267 a share.  Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com So far this year, the PHLX Semiconductor Index has increased 8.7% (with dividends reinvested), but it has declined 7.7% in April. Meanwhile, shares of industry star Nvidia Inc. have declined 12% this month.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
Boeing Stock Falls Again. The Bad News J.short_description: Boeing Stock Falls Again. The Bad News Just Keeps Piling Up.

Consumer Cos Climb on Rate, Housing Opti.title: Consumer Cos Climb on Rate, Housing Optimism -- Consumer Roundup
Consumer Cos Climb on Rate, Housing Opti.text:
Consumer companies rose amid optimism about interest rates. Consumer Price index rose 0.4% in February from January levels, in line with economists' expectations, a development that kept the prospect of 2024 rate cuts on the table for the Federal Reserve. One strategist said the gradual waning of inflation and the Fed's policy plans mean that the bull market in stocks could have legs. "We need to see earnings hold up here in the first half of the year, and continue to see upside being driven by earnings improvement and less by multiple expansion," said Eric Marshall, president of Dallas mutual-fund firm Hodges Capital. With mortgage rates stabilizing around 7%, the property market could continue to expand slowly. "The housing market to us looks stable," said Marshall. "Mortgage rates in the 7s, high 6s -- that's high enough to keep speculative building out of the market...it keeps a very healthy balance of supply and demand." Airlines slipped amid mixed earnings for discount carriers. Southwest Airlines tumbled after the discounter said it is re-evaluating its full-year financial guidance, citing uncertainty related to challenges at Boeing that are delaying aircraft deliveries. JetBlue Airways raised its first-quarter revenue outlook and said non-fuel costs rose less than the budget airline initially expected. Alaska Air said it has returned its fleet to service and now expects to top previous first-quarter performance targets despite having to ground its Boeing planes over an in-flight incident from January. Write to Rob Curran at rob.curran@dowjones.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. Industrials Gain on Economic Growth Opti.title: Industrials Gain on Economic Growth Optimism -- Industrials Roundup
Industrials Gain on Economic Growth Opti.text:
Shares of industrial and transportation companies rose amid optimism about the outlook for economic growth and interest rates. "It's an election year: there's a lot of stimulus put into the system," said Eric Marshall, president of Dallas mutual-fund firm Hodges Capital. "A lot of infrastructure spending -- things put in place in the later part of 22, are just now starting to flow into capital projects in the economy." Boeing shares fell and are now down by more than one quarter for the year to date, as Southwest Airlines said confusion caused by manufacturing delays had caused the airline's financial projections. 3M Chief Executive Mike Roman will hand off his role to defense contractor L3 Harris Technologies Chief Executive Bill Brown, moving to a role as executive chairman as the manufacturing conglomerate wrestles with litigation over "forever chemicals." Blade Air Mobility's shares fell after the provider of helicopter transportation forecast sales short of Wall Street targets. Tesla and Ford Motor were among several automakers to receive poor grades in a study that reviewed driver-assistance systems, finding little evidence the technology provides safety benefits to motorists. These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Oracl.title: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Oracle, Nvidia, Southwest, American, Acadia, On Holding, 3M, Archer Daniels, and More
These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Oracl.text:
Stocks rose on Tuesday as investors shrugged off U.S. inflation that rose more than expected in February. These stocks made moves Tuesday: 
Oracle
       reported fiscal third-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.41 a share as revenue rose 7% to $13.28 billion. Analysts had been expecting the enterprise software company to post a profit in the period of $1.38 a share on revenue of $13.3 billion. The company’s cloud infrastructure business rose 49% to $1.8 billion. CEO Safra Catz said large new cloud infrastructure contracts signed during the quarter “drove 
        Oracle’s
       total remaining performance obligations up 29% to over $80 billion—an all-time record.” Oracle said it expects cloud revenue to rise as much as 24% in the fourth quarter. Oracle shares jumped 12%. 
Nvidia
       rose 7.2%. The strong market for the company’s graphics-processing units was emphasized in Oracle’s earnings report. Oracle recently signed a new cloud-computing infrastructure deal with 
        Nvidia
       and said it plans to boost capital spending in the next fiscal year, suggesting sustained demand for AI chips. 
Southwest Airlines
       sank 15% after the carrier said it expects revenue per available seat mile in the first quarter at flat to up 2% from a year earlier, compared with previous expectations for growth of 2.5% to 4.5%. Southwest cited soft leisure travel trends. The company also said it was re-evaluating fiscal-year guidance because of lower expected deliveries of 
        Boeing
       aircraft. 
        Boeing
       was down 4.3% as details emerged regarding the Federal Aviation Administration’s six-week audit of the aerospace giant. 
American Airlines
       fell 4.7% after saying it expects an adjusted loss in the first quarter at the “low end” of its previous estimate for a loss of 15 cents to 35 cents a share because of higher fuel prices. Analysts had been expecting a loss of 22 cents.  
3M
       rose 5% after announcing that William Brown, the former chief executive of defense giant 
        L3Harris Technologies,
       will succeed the industrial company’s current CEO Michael Roman on May 1. Roman will continue as executive chairman of 3M’s board.  
Acadia Pharmaceuticals
       fell 17% after the company’s drug pimavanserin for the treatment of negative symptoms of schizophrenia didn’t demonstrate a statistically significant improvement over a placebo. “We will continue to analyze these data with our scientific advisors, but we do not intend to conduct any further clinical trials with pimavanserin,” said Acadia CEO Steve Davis. Shares of 
        Archer Daniels Midland
       rose 4% after the agricultural company said it expects fiscal-year adjusted earnings of $5.25 to $6.25 a share versus analysts’ estimates of $5.41, and its board authorized an additional $2 billion to its share buyback program. The company’s fourth-quarter earnings missed forecasts. 
On Holding
       fell 8.9% after the Swiss footwear and apparel maker issued a sales forecast for the fiscal year that missed Wall Street estimates. The company said it expects sales of $2.57 billion, below analysts’ expectations of $2.64 billion. On Holding said “negative foreign exchange impacts are expected to be more pronounced” in the first half of the year. 
Asana,
       the work management software company, reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of 4 cents a share, narrower than analysts’ expectations. 
        Asana
       said it expects an adjusted loss in the first quarter of 8 cents to 9 cents a share, in line with estimates, and revenue of $168 million to $169 million, up 10% to 11% from a year earlier. The stock fell 13%. 
New York Community Bancorp
       rose 5.9% after the regional lender said it was planning a reverse stock split after completing a deal that provided it with a $1.05 billion capital infusion from an investor group led by former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. 
Kohl’s
       reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat analysts’ estimates but sales that missed. The shares fell 6.7%. The department-store company also announced a partnership with Babies “R” Us.  
Advance Auto Parts
       said it appointed three new directors to its board and reached cooperation agreements with activist investors Third Point and Saddle Point Management. Third Point has a stake in the auto parts retailer, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday. Dan Loeb’s Third Point approached 
        Advance Auto Parts
       earlier this year with the primary goal of adding directors with experience in the industry to its board, the Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter. The stock was up 3.6%. It has declined 36% over the past 12 months.  Write to Joe Woelfel at joseph.woelfel@barrons.com JPMorgan, Walmart, and others are using the technologies to become more efficient.. That should help their stocks for the long run. Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Oracl.short_description: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Oracle, Nvidia, Southwest, American, Acadia, On Holding, 3M, Archer Daniels, and More

Airfares Have Taken Off. Why They Might.title: Airfares Have Taken Off. Why They Might Not Drop Soon.
Airfares Have Taken Off. Why They Might.text:
Airfares jumped 3.6% in February, the largest monthly rise since May 2022, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. While higher costs for labor and maintenance appear to be responsible, 
        Boeing’s
       latest troubles could help keep prices high for the rest of the year.  The latest gains continue a surge that began last summer, after a calmer spell that gave travelers a respite from the higher fares they paid in 2021 and 2022 as a result of postpandemic travel demand and higher costs for fuel. By February, airfares had gained 9% over the past seven months.  One element behind that is strikes by pilots and flight attendants that won higher wages and better benefits for airplane crews. Airlines are also facing an uptick in maintenance costs as higher flight volumes and longer hours in the air require more engine overhauls and extensive checks of the aircrafts, the companies have said. In 2023, the cost of maintenance and repair at 
        United Airlines Holdings
       increased 27% from the previous year, while salaries and benefits for staff went up by 29%, lifting total operating expenses by 16%. Maintenance and salary costs grew by double digits at other major airlines as well. Higher operating costs mean that airlines have to either accept lower margins or raise ticket prices. Many airlines have increased baggage fees in recent weeks to boost revenue.  While demand for travel is growing strongly—the Airports Council International has forecast that global passenger traffic would increase 12% in 2024 to surpass the 2019 level for the first time—putting more planes in the air to carry the extra passengers is likely to be harder than usual.  
Boeing’s
       recent safety crisis has led to disruptions in its schedule of plane deliveries. Regulators are investigating the aerospace company’s safety standards and production process in response to a January mid-flight incident in which an emergency-door plug blew out of a 737 MAX 9 jet. The plane landed with a gaping hole in its fuselage. The ensuing probe into Boeing’s safety standards and production process could leave airlines with fewer airplanes than expected this summer at the busiest time of the year. Multiple carriers have warned recently that their plans to increase capacity could be hurt by delivery delays from Boeing.  During its Tuesday earnings call, 
        Southwest Airlines
       management said Boeing expects to deliver 12 fewer MAX 8 aircraft than the previously expected 58. To adjust to the changes, the firm could delay planned plane retirements, which would likely lead to higher maintenance costs, or reduce its flight capacity. Southwest is leaning towards the latter. Management said the firm expects 2024 capacity to grow between 4.5% and 5% after a cut of 1 to 1.5 percentage points from the impact of the Boeing delays. But the impact would be primarily focused on post-peak summer schedules, the company said. Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. Southwest Is Latest Airline With a Serio.title: Southwest Is Latest Airline With a Serious Boeing Problem
Southwest Is Latest Airline With a Serio.text:
Southwest Airlines
       is getting fewer aircraft this year than it previously expected as issues at 
        Boeing
       intensify. 
Southwest,
       which strictly uses Boeing jets, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday that Boeing told the airline to expect 46 deliveries of the 737-8 plane in 2024, less than the previously expected 79. “As a result of Boeing’s continued challenges, the Company expects the delivery schedule to be fluid and, therefore, plans to reduce capacity and re-optimize schedules, primarily for the back half of 2024, which will likely result in at least a one point reduction to the Company’s full year 2024 capacity plans on a year-over-year basis,” Southwest said in the filing. Shares of Southwest were falling 15% to $28.85 and were on pace for their largest percentage decrease since March 12, 2020, according to Dow Jones Market Data. The stock was the worst performer in the 
        S&P 500
       Tuesday, while the index gained 0.7%. Boeing stock has dropped 29% so far this year, as the aircraft maker has had a challenging couple of months. An Alaska Air Group flight had to conduct in emergency landing in January after an emergency-door plug blew out on a 737 MAX 9. This led to the temporary grounding of the aircrafts. Then on March 4, the Federal Aviation Administration said it had found multiple instances where Boeing allegedly failed to comply with manufacturing quality control requirements. The U.S. Justice Department is also opening a criminal investigation into the Alaska Air flight that resulted in the emergency landing, The Wall Street Journal reported on Saturday. Southwest’s announcement on Tuesday comes as airlines get ready for the J.P. Morgan Industrials Conference later in the day. In preparation for the conference, Alaska Air said in a regulatory filing that as a result of the door incident and the grounding, “our profitability was negatively impacted by at least $150 million.” Alaska Air said it has “received partial compensation from Boeing,” which will be accounted for in first-quarter earnings. “Our adjusted loss-per-share expectation reflects this compensation, and approximately ($0.30) remaining impact from the grounding.” Also, Alaska Air said it has returned its fleet “safely to service and restored our schedule,” and first-quarter performance is on track to exceed previous expectations. 
American Airlines Group
       updated its first-quarter financial estimates without mentioning Boeing in a regulatory filing on Tuesday. The airline now expects its first-quarter adjusted loss per share to be at the low end of previous guidance for a loss of 15 cents to 35 cents, as fuel prices “increased considerably.” American Airlines stock was down 4.4% Tuesday while shares of Alaska Air Group were up 1%. Boeing whistleblower reportedly found de.title: Boeing whistleblower reportedly found dead in South Carolina
Boeing whistleblower reportedly found de.text:
A retired Boeing quality-control engineer described as a company whistleblower was found dead in his truck in the parking lot of a South Carolina hotel after he failed to show up for the second part of his testimony in a lawsuit against the company, according to a published report Monday. John Barnett, 62, had raised safety concerns about the airline’s factories and provided testimony just days before he was found dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, the Charleston County coroner reportedly told the BBC. Barnett’s attorney, Brian Knowles, was quoted as having told TMZ that he had doubts about the circumstances of Knowles’s death, calling the self-inflicted gunshot “alleged.” “Today is a tragic day,” Knowles reportedly told Corporate Crime Reporter. “John had been back and forth for quite some time getting prepared. The defense examined him for their allowed seven hours under the rules on Thursday.” The whistleblower was said to have been staying at the hotel while he provided a deposition in a whistleblower lawsuit against the company. Knowles and his co-counsel had been calling Barnett’s phone on Saturday, but the calls went to voicemail, according to Knowles. “We then asked the hotel to check on him,” he said. “They found him in his truck dead from an alleged self-inflicted gunshot.  An email to Knowles, quoted as having said he spoke with police and the coroner at the hotel, was not immediately returned Monday night. Barnett was said to have worked for Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.29%
       for over three decades before retiring in 2017. He worked as a quality-control engineer. In 2019, Barnett told the BBC that Boeing had compromised safety by rushing to get its 787 Dreamliner off the production line, alleging that up to a quarter of onboard oxygen systems could be faulty and not functional if needed. Boeing released a statement on Barnett’s death. “We are saddened by Mr. Barnett’s passing, and our thoughts are with his family and friends,” the statement read. The company has been under heightened scrutiny in recent months due to myriad of issues concerning its planes, including an incident in January when a door plug blew off during an Alaska Airlines flight. A version of this report appeared at NYPost.com. Read on: Buttigieg says Boeing needs ‘a serious transformation’ amid alarming quality concerns  Intel’s bad year is getting worse as the chip stock experiences another sharp slide in the wake of earnings. Air New Zealand Pauses Chicago Flights D.title: Air New Zealand Pauses Chicago Flights Due to Engine Shortage -- 2nd Update
Air New Zealand Pauses Chicago Flights D.text:
By Stuart Condie and Ben Otto SYDNEY--Air New Zealand will pause one of the world's longest non-stop flights for up to six months due to what the carrier said is a shortage of engines for its Boeing Dreamliner aircraft. New Zealand's national carrier on Tuesday said it would pause its non-stop Auckland-Chicago service from March 31. It cited challenges related to the availability of serviceable Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 engines. "Rolls-Royce has been unable to provide Air New Zealand with spare or replacement engines to deliver the level of service needed, leading to a reduction in the amount of flying Air New Zealand can deliver via its 787 fleet," it said. The airline said the Trent 1000 engines normally require being removed from aircraft and sent to the manufacturer for inspection after 1,000 engine cycles of take-offs and landings, but that Air New Zealand engineers had determined maintenance was required after 750-850 cycles. The airline added that while up to three aircraft will be "unavailable for an extended period," it will maintain its schedule of up to 35 flights weekly to six ports across the U.S. and Canada. The carrier's fleet comprised 105 aircraft at the end of October, including 14 Boeing 787 jets. Air New Zealand began offering three non-stop Auckland-Chicago flights weekly in late 2018. The route takes about 15-16 hours, making it one of the world's longest non-stop flights. The airline said the decision to pause the service wasn't likely to affect the fiscal 2024 guidance it issued in February. Air New Zealand said last month it expects annual pretax earnings of between 200 million New Zealand dollars (US$123.4 million) and NZ$240 million. Last month, Rolls-Royce Chief Executive Tufan Erginbilgic said the wait times for Trent 1000 engines had doubled. He said Rolls-Royce expects Boeing and the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration to certify a new blade this year, which should improve the engine's durability. The engine manufacturer has also been affected by supply chain issues, he said on a call with investors. "Across the industry in aerospace, there are bottlenecks caused by both labor and parts shortages," Erginbilgic said. Air New Zealand is already grappling with an engine shortage from a global recall of hundreds of Pratt & Whitney jet engines. Last month, the carrier said it anticipates NZ$35 million of fiscal second-half costs due to the recall, which forced it to revise flight schedules and lease aircraft. Write to Stuart Condie at stuart.condie@wsj.com and Ben Otto at ben.otto@wsj.com Microsoft and Alphabet's CEOs both called out their use of Nvidia chips in earnings calls. U.K. Labor Market Cools Slightly as Bank.title: U.K. Labor Market Cools Slightly as Bank of England Weighs Rate Cuts -- Update
U.K. Labor Market Cools Slightly as Bank.text:
By Ed Frankl U.K. wage growth eased marginally, as the unemployment rate ticked up, a small relief to Bank of England policymakers hoping that labor pressures would ease ahead of expected interest-rate cuts later this year. The headline measure of average annual pay growth, excluding bonuses, was 6.1% in the three months to January, compared with 6.2% in the final quarter of 2023, a fifth fall in as many months, according to data published Tuesday by the Office for National Statistics. The rate was the lowest since October 2022. Meanwhile, the rate of joblessness grew to 3.9% between November and January, a little higher than the 3.8% in the three months to December, it said. It compares with expectations that wage growth and unemployment would hold steady at 6.2% and 3.8% respectively, according to economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. Including bonuses, annual wage growth eased to 5.6% in November-January, from 5.8% in the three months to December, the ONS said. "Recent trends in the jobs market are continuing with earnings, in cash terms, growing more slowly than recently but, thanks to lower inflation, real terms pay continues to increase," the ONS's director of economic statistics Liz McKeown, said. The U.K.'s annual inflation was 4.0% in January, the same as December. Falling wage growth could mean the BOE would be more comfortable with lowering interest rates, though wage pressures remain high and unemployment is near its historic low. Indeed, despite encouraging signs of a more marked slowdown, the ease in wage growth in January is probably still a bit too slow for the Bank of England's liking, Paul Dales, Chief U.K. economist at Capital Economics, said in a research note. A rise in the minimum wage at the start of April could also put further pressure on wages. The central bank meets next on March 21. However, a further fall in job vacancies--to 908,000 in the three months to February from 928,000 in the three months to January--suggests the labor market continues to loosen, Dales added. If wage growth continues to cool, and inflation falls below the BOE's 2.0% target in April, that could be enough to prompt the bank to cut rates in the summer, he said. Opinion: Oracle finally becomes a cloud.title: Opinion: Oracle finally becomes a cloud company, helped by ‘enormous’ AI demand
Opinion: Oracle finally becomes a cloud.text:
Oracle Corp. has reached an important milestone in its decade-long shift to becoming a cloud-computing company — revenue from the cloud surpassed its traditional software licensing revenue for the first time. Oracle Chief Executive Safra Catz touted that fact on the company’s conference call with analysts Monday while discussing its better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter earnings. Oracle shares 
        ORCL,
        +2.05%
       jumped 14% in after-hours trading, ending the session at $130.50. The company’s total cloud revenue jumped 24% in the quarter, while its software-licensing revenue was down 3%. Executives talked about continued strong demand for its cloud services, and how Oracle is building more data centers to keep up with demand, which is also being fueled by the need for more generative-AI infrastructure. “We have enormous amounts of demand,” Catz said, adding that there are many new customers that have not reached their capacity yet. When asked about her projections to nearly double capital spending to $10 billion in fiscal 2025, she said it was necessary to build out more data centers and expand existing ones.   Oracle co-founder and Chief Technology Officer Larry Ellison described one massive data center in Salt Lake City currently under construction. ”You can park eight Boeing 747s nose-to-tail in that one data center,” he said.  The company is also getting a lot of interest from governments seeking to create so-called sovereign clouds, a cloud infrastructure designed exclusively for the security needs of government entities and their institutions.  However, even while projecting a 22% to 24% increase in total cloud revenue for the fiscal fourth quarter,  Catz also guided non-GAAP earnings to a range of down 2% to flattish, between $1.62 and $1.66 share. She noted that as the company’s cloud capacity fills up, margins will rise. Oracle may also be seeing an impact from its big spending and focus on low prices for cloud services. Also read: Oracle was late in the cloud but now its stock could win big. With its massive data-center buildout and crossover in revenue, Oracle can now truly call itself a major player in the cloud. But how sustainable that demand is remains the big question, as many investors  try to find companies besides the obvious chip makers — like Nvidia Corp. 
        NVDA,
        +5.98%
       — that will benefit from AI.   Southwest Airlines Co.’s stock tumbled 9% Thursday after the airline posted a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and revenue that lagged estimates. Therese Poletti writes the "Tech Tales" column for MarketWatch. Follow her on Twitter @tpoletti. Therese Poletti writes the "Tech Tales" column for MarketWatch. Follow her on Twitter @tpoletti. Buttigieg says Boeing needs \u2018a seri.title: Buttigieg says Boeing needs ‘a serious transformation’ amid alarming quality concerns
Buttigieg says Boeing needs \u2018a seri.text:
With Boeing facing multiple government investigations, the company needs to make “a serious transformation” around its safety and manufacturing quality, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said Monday. The comments came one day after Buttigieg said the aircraft builder is under “enormous” scrutiny by his department since a panel blew off a Boeing 737 Max jetliner in midlfight. Over the weekend, the Wall Street Journal reported that the Department of Justice launched a criminal investigation into the Jan. 5 blowout on an Alaska Airlines jet. That followed the company’s admission that it couldn’t find records that the National Transportation Safety Board sought for work done on the panel at a Boeing factory. The Federal Aviation Administration, part of Buttigieg’s department, is also investigating Boeing 
        BA,
        +0.26%.
 “Obviously we respect the independence of DOJ (the Department of Justice) and NTSB (the National Transportation Safety Board) doing their own work,” Buttigieg told reporters Monday, “but we are not neutral on the question of whether Boeing should fully cooperate with any entity — NTSB, us, or DOJ. They should, and we expect them to.” Buttigieg said Boeing must “go through a serious transformation here in terms of their responsiveness, their culture and their quality issues.” Boeing gave a one-sentence response. “We will continue to cooperate fully and transparently with all government investigations and audits, as we take comprehensive action to improve safety and quality at Boeing,” the company said. Alaska Airlines 
        ALK,
        -1.09%
       said it is cooperating with the Justice Department investigation. “In an event like this, it’s normal for the DOJ to be conducting an investigation,” the Seattle-based airline said in a statement. “We are fully cooperating and do not believe we are a target of the investigation.” Last week, Boeing, which is based in Arlington, Virginia, came under withering criticism by NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy over the missing work records on the Alaska jet. She told a Senate committee that Boeing had repeatedly rebuffed her agency’s attempts to get information ever since the blowout. Boeing disputed some of Homendy’s claims; NTSB stood by her testimony. The FAA has barred Boeing from boosting production of Max jets and gave the company 90 days to come up with a plan to fix quality-control issues. A surprisingly high inflation reading in the first quarter has raised anxiety about whether a key price index in March could be worse than expected and could lower the odds of U.S. interest-rate cuts. These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Nvidi.title: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Nvidia, Boeing, MicroStrategy, PDD, EQT, Choice Hotels, Duolingo, and More
These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Nvidi.text:
Stocks were mixed on Monday as investors turned their attention to U.S. inflation data in the coming days. These stocks made moves Monday: 
Nvidia
       dipped 0.2% after the chip maker shed $128 billion in market cap on Friday, the company’s largest drop on record. 
        Nvidia
       closed down 5.6% on Friday, the largest percentage decrease for the shares since May 31, 2023, when they fell 5.7%. The company was sued Friday over allegedly using copyrighted works in training artificial-intelligence systems.  
Boeing
       fell 3% after The Wall Street Journal reported the Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into the 
        Boeing
       737 MAX jet that experienced a blowout on an Alaska Airlines flight in early January. The Journal, citing documents and people familiar with the matter, said investigators have contacted some passengers and crew on the Jan. 5 flight. The Federal Aviation Administration grounded all MAX 9 jets after the incident. They returned to service after all required repairs were made and the planes were inspected. 
Coinbase
       fell 1% and 
        MicroStrategy
       rose 4.1% as the crypto-related companies reacted to 
        Bitcoin’s
       moves. The world’s largest cryptocurrency at last check was at $72,171.63, up 3.8% over the past 24 hours. It set a record high of $72,716 earlier. U.S.-listed shares of 
        PDD Holdings,
       the Chinese e-commerce company, rose 1.4% after Jefferies upgraded the stock to Buy from Hold. Analysts at Goldman Sachs, however, downgraded PDD to Neutral From Buy. 
EQT
       declined 7.8% after the company confirmed it reached a deal to buy back 
        Equitrans Midstream,
       its former unit. The company will have an initial enterprise value of more than $35 billion. 
Wyndham Hotels & Resorts
       rose 2.4% after 
        Choice Hotels
       said it was ending its attempted takeover of the rival hotel chain. 
        Choice Hotels
       said its exchange offer to buy 
        Wyndham
       shares has expired and it was withdrawing its nominations to Wyndham’s board. Choice Hotels also said its board approved an increase to its buyback program of five million shares. Choice Hotels was up 5.4%. 
Duolingo
       gained 4.3% to $222.64 after shares of the language learning company were initiated with a Buy recommendation at 
        J.P. Morgan
       and price target of $270. Analyst Bryan Smilek thinks 
        Duolingo
       can boost revenue at a compounded average growth rate of 27% through 2026.  Analysts forecast 
        Oracle
       will post fiscal third-quarter earnings of $1.38 a share on revenue of $13.28 billion, up 7.2% from a year earlier. The enterprise software company earned $1.22 a share in last year’s third quarter. 
        Oracle’s
       cloud computing business has been growing faster than its rivals but capacity issues have constrained that growth. Oracle shares were up 1.5% ahead of the report, scheduled for after the closing bell Monday. Reports are expected later in the week from 
        On Holding,
Kohl’s,
Lennar,
Dollar Tree,
Williams-Sonoma,
UiPath,
SentinelOne,
Adobe,
Dollar General,
Ulta Beauty,
Archer Daniels Midland,
Dick’s Sporting Goods,
Smartsheet,
       and 
        Jabil.
 Write to Joe Woelfel at joseph.woelfel@barrons.com Tesla stock has risen for three consecutive days, after falling for seven straight.  Visit a quote page and your recently viewed tickers will be displayed here.
